review: I haven't beaten this yet, but it is a great game. I don't know anything else quite like it and it makes it hard to describe. It is a card game, time is a factor, there is no rule book. Pro tip- don't work at the office too long without getting promoted.

The thing that will kill you is the lack of distinction between deadly and harmless things. Bleak Thoughts 1 looks the same as Bleak Thoughts Instakill, and for good measure could have spawned in a corner off screen.

Brutally difficult, you will die, often. You will win unsatisfactorily, often unexpectedly. You may build a powerful cult only to have it all come undone in a quick series of unfortunate cards. You can end up sabotaging yourself by choosing incompatible upgrade paths and find your path forwards forever barred. Most of the game is spent watching timers tick down while you try to keep your list of future actions in mind. ;It's enough to make you die from dread.;It is however captivating. ;The lore and setting is full Lovecraftian. If you unironically enjoy the process of sorting large numbers of things, it can be very pleasing to get a good system perfectly laid out. On that note I wish some of the card moving and stacking mechanics worked a bit better. ;Recommended, but know the price you pay.
Best Indie game ever.

Pretentious nonsense "game" that would insist on being called a film if it were a movie. ;;The not having a tutorial is a bad sign, but it's not a deal breaker. What is a deal breaker is that nothing engaging happens to make me care to figure out the game. Lots of people (although not myself) had issues with their devs previous game Sunless Sea because it wasn't the exploring/trading game they wanted. It was a story driven game where you did explore the world, but none of the ship-captain-game tropes applied. to it. ;;The problem here is that it dispenses with the story which means there's no real reason to do the work to figure out the game. I'm not going to eat bowl after bowl of plain oatmeal just in case there's a steak later, and when I feel like playing a game where the devs hid the good stuff I'll just fire up Hidden Folks.

One of my favorite games I've ever played. Incredible writing mixes with minimalist story-telling to create an infinitely deep well of mystery and intrigue. Fair warning, however: this is also perhaps the hardest game I've ever played. The mechanics are intricate and delicate, requiring an incredible amount of skill and patience. Now, having beat it 30+ times, it's become a comfort game for me, and I've come back to it again and again after years of playing. Listen to the opening scrawl: "You won't always know what to do next. Keep experimenting, and you'll master it."

This game is fantastic. A real gem. Had a blast learning mechanics and all the weird funky interactions you can do. Had real fun assembling my cult team Ocean 11 style while keeping it on the DL from the Dream Police. One of my character's occult research was financed entirely by sugar daddies lmao. I don't want to spoil any mechanics so I'll leave it at that but make sure not to look up any guides and just explore the game on your own. You will get a real kick out of it if you like Lovecraftian story telling. Gifted it to my friend too hehe. Gotta spread the love.

一款杀时间，电波系的rogue向卡牌游戏，推荐给有足够时间且对神秘学有些许兴趣的玩家;虽然是一款以类克苏鲁风格为背景做世界观的游戏，但其游戏本身并无任何类克苏鲁风格的恐怖元素 [strike] 可以放心大胆挖掘游戏内秘史设定并入迷 [/strike];游戏中最关键且有趣的部分在于探索，这一过程在对游戏了解越少的时候是越有趣的，但也因为对游戏了解不足，极其容易出现反复bed end的情况，需要足够的耐心与兴趣支撑 [spoiler] 或者可以去问万能的wiki [/spoiler] [spoiler] 毕竟游戏内几乎没有任何形式的引导 [/spoiler];一些不涉及游戏内剧透的小技巧，如果你刚刚游玩这款游戏，且总是莫名其妙的bed end导致没办法继续进行游戏不妨点开看看;[spoiler] 1.游戏内所有卡牌与卡槽都具有属于自己的“性相”拥有与卡槽相同性相的卡牌才能放进卡槽，如果你不知道自己能做什么，不妨看看有哪些卡槽的性相与手牌相同 [/spoiler];[spoiler] 2.游戏内部分卡牌具有时限，如果你想用这些有时限的卡去做某些事但时间来不及，不妨把它拖进可用的卡槽中，开着卡槽界面继续游戏试试 [/spoiler];[spoiler] 3.如果你因为一些操作失误而出现和原本预期大相径庭的结果，不妨试试ctrl+~，这是游戏内置的工作台，你甚至可以用它作弊（不推荐，这会失去游戏内很大一部分的乐趣） [/spoiler]

优点：极为优秀的本地化文本，宏大而诡谲的神秘学世界，前期丰富的探索感;;缺点：中后期重复度高，流程引导极为晦涩（不过引导晦涩这一点算是文本优秀代入感强的负面效应），每轮游戏时间过长，不方便后期探索路线，并且无明显节点导致玩起来容易疲惫;;28h打了灯教小胜（灯教当时不会玩创的是启教所以二周目开局就没办法玩下去很气）、铸教小胜、铸教大胜三个结局，现在已经完全疲惫了，中途反复想着呜呜呜打一次大胜结局就不想再玩了累死了;;对阅读不排斥、对神秘学感兴趣、有耐心的玩家非常建议入手体验一下。新手玩不懂看教学估计也很懵，可以自己探索一段时间之后看看wiki，挺方便的;哦对了，笔记本的小屏幕玩起来好痛苦！玩的时候一直想着要是我也有大屏幕就好了TAT

非常好玩，非常上头，非常策略，唯一就是这个游戏很解谜，对萌新没有任何教程，但是游戏是好游戏，就是每开一把都要玩很久，特别前期拉三维，招人和买书要很久，但是每开一把都很上瘾，还有各种各样的成就和结局，有时候为了拿某个成就会故意死一把，因为萌新玩几把基本就会了不容易死，但是有些成就需要失败解锁，但是赢一把要很长时间，除了基础那几个开局好一点，DLC拓展包的玩法真的是又麻烦又浪费时间，但是好玩就完了，建议打折入手，我是之前打折买的五折还是六折买的，原价买感觉有点小贵，因为这个游戏要买全，没有DLC的开局很平淡，DLC会增加其他开局，其他飞升方式，和特定的故事和各种结局

好玩，对味。风格独特精致，玩法有趣有创意，游戏内容丰富有深度，文本翻译精巧又晦涩。;;在桌面上体验一个为了生计上班的普通打工仔，一步步探索秘闻，成立密教，培养信徒，进行仪式，最终飞升的故事。;游戏提供了8种各不相同的秘传路线，以及多种胜利结局，足以让每次的游戏都有新的玩法。;美中不足是游戏中后期的流程比较重复。

很多開局都有正常人生的結局，認真工作，安穩一生，這在遊戲中並不困難。;那麼，是什麼驅使你追求超凡的飛升之路？;遵循慾望，探索秘密，躲避追緝，提升自我，直到跨過凡人的界線，這就是密教模擬器特別的主題。;這是困難的道路，實際上你完全沒有路標，遊戲不提供新手教學，開局直接把自己嚇死或迷失自我都是常有的，在常世中跌跌撞撞也是種遊戲體驗的樂趣。;遊戲的氣氛非常好，圖畫/文字/事件設計都非常有神祕感，雖然美術演出相對少，大多是卡牌，但氣氛到位，一張桌子就道盡精彩的故事。;但一定要提一下，太漫長了，一局長規結局來到了10小時+，當你熟知處世之道，後面就變化不大，作業感很重。;我給好評，只是我再也沒有精力展開另一次求道之旅了，穿越純白之門消耗了我的體力，我的容器已疲勞，精神則化為評論來到了這裡。
如果一个人没有通关异教徒模拟器，那么他应该会度过一个略带遗憾的人生。

A very good design for a experience, where your mind is freed from all that is known, and your walls are torn down. You shall fall, you shall fail, and in the visions of your past, you will find the glimmer of victory. You shall burn eternal, you shall see light forever, you shall thirst forever.;Buy this game if you want to learn how to write deep metaphors with a pinch of dread. And also cards.

召异神，逐忌宝。奉信条，创密教。;被抛入一个卡牌组成的世界，你手上只拥有 （卑贱的工作）和（理性）两个选择。;向卡池投掷卡牌，从事「卑贱的工作」，搬砖容易失去 「健康」，陷入疾病威胁。投入「理性」，你会找到一份轻松点的文职工作，但一不小心就成会 996 的社畜。;两个选择都不是完美的选项，何况金钱还会时刻随着时间流逝。;这个世界最大的意外来自一份密教的断章，密语写成，艰涩万分。即使没有完全看懂，里面神异却开始扰乱你的思维。教义、仪式、传说中的神明低语，恐惧情绪主宰你的精神，你不得不到书店和拍卖行寻找更多的书籍来解读。;你不断和周围的熟人谈论它，变得举止神秘，行踪可疑，以至于警察盯上了你，断章的蛛丝马迹爬满生活。;不被黑暗同化，就被黑暗吞噬。但谁知道，被同化是不是被吞噬的一种方式？对恶龙的恐惧让人成为恶龙本身。作为一个 996 打工仔，你悲剧地发现你的宿命是应神的启示，建立密教，召集信徒，对抗你的敌人。;一次次入梦，在漫宿中惊鸿一瞥，在超脱的道路上越升越高。;最终成就飞升，超越启示本身，甚至为后进者指引道路。;

神中神，手机上玩了几十个小时，无论是卡牌元素还是密教元素都是顶尖，文案更是一绝。游戏过程不推荐查攻略,探寻未知的过程才是这个游戏的最大乐趣。

I love this game's writing. I love this game's art. I love the sense of unfolding discovery and exploration, the way that the tone of the game escalates as you dig yourself deeper. Cultist Simulator doesn't so much build a world as burn it into the blank slate of the card table, creating scorch marks and lightning trees that gesture at occult secrets. It really does feel like you're snatching revelations from your dreams and taking them back to the world and using them to turn people into zealous followers.;;That said, after hours and hours of unwinding and digging and burning... I found what was under all that work pretty empty. I won't get into the specific mechanics in case you still want to discover them, but the game is fundamentally about time management and keeping plates spinning, but I kept feeling like I didn't have enough control over those plates. The game expects you to grind and grind and build up resources gradually, but also expects you to start all over when an unlucky break makes you lose everything - a recipe in redundancy and repetition. And that's not really for me.

[h1]密教模拟器是一个时刻令玩家充满探索欲望的文字冒险游戏[/h1];;优点：;-精简的卡牌与ui;-庞大的文字量，本地化中文将原版怪诞神秘的克苏鲁风格展现的淋漓尽致;-[strike]骨子里的反社会[/strike];缺点：;-中后期少量的重复性;-缺少指引;[spoiler]-过多的成就[/spoiler];;这款游戏对于密教，邪典爱好者来说不可多得，得益于作者优秀的文笔，我也确实一次又一次的体会到了探索的乐趣，就像作者在采访中所说，这款游戏没有一秒钟的cg，因为他不需要，他每时每刻都在用不同的方式向我们讲述隐藏在游戏后的故事。可以看的出制作者尽可能的减少了重复性，不过缺少指引也导致了重复性的必然发生。我在游戏过程中不可抗力的搜索了攻略，搜索的同时减少了很多乐趣。不建议查攻略。;;评分：;9/10
时间大杀手，想买的注意这个。好玩是真的好玩。

It's a fun game for people who are good at thinking and planning ahead. The best thing about it is honestly just how it teaches you what to do. Every failure is never actually a failure, but a lesson that'll take you further next time. It never gets boring, since it keeps you on your toes at all times, and it's bound to get you hooked. Definitely buy and play, if you like tabletop strategy games.

Few games can rival this one in quality of writing; its music is well composed and interesting; its art is simple and eerie; but it is the mechanics and total lack of tutorial that make this game fantastic. Part deckbuilder, part resource management, part pause-and-play strategy, the occult themes of this game will interest players of many different backgrounds and genres. Play this for a view into the creepiness of Victorian England.

Cultist Simulator takes a while to grow on you, but when you get it, you get it. ;;It's halfway between a plate-spinning game and a card game. You have cards, which represent resources, places, etc. You have verbs, which... you know... DO things. And you feed cards into verbs to get new cards. Simple, right?;;No. Not even close.;;For such a simple interface, there's a lot of exploration, experimentation, and fumbling around in the dark. It feels like trying to get the arcane details of a prayer to an elder god right. So... yeah, 100%% appropriate. It also has brilliant worldbuilding.
I have no idea what I'm doing. :)

文本和音乐我给满分，OST真的很值得入，很适合晚上写作的时候听[spoiler]入迷+1[/spoiler];文本真的让我学了很多，顺便抄了一些，也仿照这写了一些，很有尼采哲学的感觉[spoiler]入迷+2[/spoiler];;但游戏性算不上神作，只能算作精品，没有教程对我来说倒无所谓，我玩游戏喜欢的是摸索的过程，但是对于大部分玩家来讲就是很不友好的现象了，但从新人的角度来讲不去查攻略通关的难度实在是太高了，漫无目的的探索很容易失去耐心[spoiler]躁动+3[/spoiler];;虽说是类ROGUE类游戏，但实际上重复性非常大，可以理解为带有随机影响的多线性游戏，虽然有不少角色，但是大部分角色（主要是还是基础角色）的通关方式其实是一样的，对于熟练游戏之后，可玩性就会大大下降，不过这也足够了，毕竟这是个剧情向游戏，而不是可以重复游玩的ROGUELIKE游戏[spoiler]需要置入激情[/spoiler]
好玩
Delightful. Deceptively simple and deceptively complex at the same time.

An Absolute gem of a game, the lore is great and when you add a bit of imagination to your actions it's an awesome story generator. For example, I hired a bomb-maker hireling and took out the younger elder. It has it's own text to convey what happened but doesn't go into detail of how. So in my mind the person I hired hit him with a car bomb outside a bar. Be warned it does not hold your hand and you will probably die a lot until you figure out how things work. That however is also part of the story because in your next play through it will reference your last character. Highly recommend.

One of the most impressive aspects of Cultist Simulator is its storytelling. The game features a rich and complex narrative that unfolds gradually as players progress through the game. The writing is excellent, with a sense of foreboding and unease permeating every aspect of the game. Players will find themselves drawn into the game's world, and the sense of mystery and discovery is incredibly satisfying.;The game's art style is also noteworthy, with a distinctive hand-drawn aesthetic that perfectly complements the game's themes and tone. The sound design is also excellent, with an evocative and eerie soundtrack that adds to the game's overall atmosphere.;One potential drawback of Cultist Simulator is its steep learning curve. The game can be challenging to understand and master, with many complex mechanics and systems to navigate. However, for players willing to invest the time and effort to learn the game's intricacies, the rewards are well worth it.

This game is extremely difficult with a STEEP learning curve, which makes victories that much sweeter when they come. I love a cultist theme, the world that is built, and even the difficulty. If you like a game that is very punishing but also extremely rewarding, and you love puzzles, and you love occult themes then please give this game a try.

Great writing and worldbuilding, but the core gameplay loop feels like one long grind to acquire and level up lore fragments. Plus, to do so, you need certain temporary resources, but you don't know which ones ahead of time. You have to find out by trial and error (wasting some in the process), or by checking the wiki. I'm sure you can do some cool stuff if you put in the time to get high-level lore, but it doesn't seem worth it to me.

I can deal with the lack of hints on on how to advance further, part of the experimentation process I guess, I can deal with the many lore books, aspects and such with no explanation as to what to do with them. 非常有创意的游戏。相比于传统文本类 游戏 sunless sea这种，我觉得可能目前的游戏形式反而更舒适。但也许是我年纪大了-》-》。;;anyway，80~90%%的好评基本属实。确实总体来讲还是有很多缺陷的。;游戏内容，文本深度是有的，但是机制后期重复，属于初期眼前一亮，但是玩久了就发现比较平庸的那种 idea型游戏。受众大概是对克苏鲁题材之类比较有瘾的玩家，普通玩家可能玩不了多久。;;个人建议是 先不买DLC，如果游戏本体就已经让你略感乏味了，那么DLC内容并不能拯救。（然而我已经一次性买齐无法后悔了）;;总体来讲是一个上瘾性质的 看文本 小游戏，但是这个idea的创意分是要给的。不然也不能骗到我-》-》。;;回正体。;音乐方面中轨中距，卡牌交互的特效声之类的都还行，后期重复无法避免。;;游戏文本体量还是很不错的，有点像魂类型游戏 可以自嗨，也有很多下了功夫的痕迹在内。;;游戏机制 颇具创意，类似桌游，每个卡牌都是自己的特质label，不同label放一起进行不同作业有不同互动。本身这个 结合形式 是非常不错的，也让人感觉自己 颇具 密教大头头的 氛围。但是内容后期实在有些重复，一旦熟悉 套路和组合，变成了 资源累积 的机械操作，而游戏并没有 支持很好的自动化作业 （比如一个勾选框，如果勾选了，作业完成后会 自动重新进行用同样的素材卡牌进行 作业 之类），这种优化程度的提高并没有被实施，不过也能理解，毕竟制作组第一次进行这样的开发，可能还受到文本类游戏的影响。但是 后果是，玩家会感受到，后期了，自己只是被迫 按在电脑前，时不时得手动操作电脑 。比较致命，这个优化 如果实在想不好怎么弄，也可以参考 放置游戏等等。;;总体来说，这是一款文本内容较多，各个方面都还算用心，也有创意，但是 制作略显考虑不周，导致 实际游戏体验内容不多的 克苏鲁 题材游戏。但 目前的状态 还是有点贵，价格对不起游戏体验。

Great atmosphere, horrible design.;;The game is about picking up cards to see what activities get highlighted as usable with the card you're holding. If you don't derive enjoyment from clicking and dragging to see what highlights on your screen, this game isn't for you.;;If you do, for some odd reason, enjoy such gameplay I still can't recommend this game. The mid/late-game experience is all about manually organizing a million different resources, losing track of one, and pulling your hair out when you accidentally commit to some other action because you thought the resources that got lost among your other cards expired and now that you found it its too late to change your selection.;;The fundamental problem with this game is that it should not have been a card game. It should've been a game that keeps track of your available health/passion/reason/funds in UI bars similar to how other games handle Health Points or Mana, keeps track of locations on some kind of map, and keeps track of your inventory in a fucking inventory menu. Nope, instead, you'll have all of these on one massive table, and you'll have to sort them manually yourself if you want any hope at playing through the mid-game. The majority of the difficulty actually comes from managing the cards on your table, not the game's actual challenges. Seriously, this game's design seems like some kind of cruel joke.;;Do not waste your money.

I absolutely adore this game, but it isn't for everyone. Cultist Sim plays like a card-based board game with a heavy emphasis on time management and putting out fires. The best part of this game is the lore that's drip fed to you in different item descriptions. You play a character that's taking their first steps into an (highly developed, internally consistent) occult underground, trying to scrape together whatever small pieces of knowledge you can find to piece by piece understand and harness the world you're diving into. Reading everything is mandatory to enjoying this game. If you don't like theorizing and trying to draw connections between pieces of lore, turn back now. The actual mechanics of the game can be deeply frustrating, in part because they are intentionally obfuscated. This frustration is made worse by the fact that a successful run in this game can be very long, and defeat can come unexpectedly and wipe away hours of work. This is a pretty major flaw, and I bounced off of this game three or four times before it stuck. If you're willing to stick it out though, there's an excellent experience waiting for you. If you enjoyed House of Leaves, Sunless Sea, Underhanded (a phone game), Fallen London, or the stories of H.P. Lovecraft, give this game a shot. There's another game coming out in a few months set in the same world that I'm very excited about, so if you end up enjoying Cultist Sim there's more on the way!

I have a love/hate relationship with this game. I love everything about it [i]except[/i] the game play. People commonly fall back to Dark Souls as a comparison for difficult games because above all else, Dark Souls is fair. It does not give a shit if you are the main character, you are not special, you will die like the rest. Cultist Simulator is not a fair game. It knows you're the main character and will punish you for it. The mechanics are drenched in mystique to the point where you will get challenges you could not possible have prepared for, and it will crush you all the way back to the start over and over again.There are a few things I want to specifically call out:The new game system. New games aren't really 'new', how you can start a run is based on how the last run ended. Where this matters most is after a 'Standard' victory you get a special start that is effectively new game+ with added mechanics, a special victory condition, and a little boost to start. Here's the thing though, as with everything else, the game explains none of it. It is not a fun mystery to solve or riddle to crack because the punishment is so heavy. Because you can ONLY start those runs immediately after beating a standard victory, if you lose the only way to give it another shot is to [b]beat the game again.[/b] One victory, one chance, hope you wanted to play another 20 hours to get back to the start.Magnets. The magnet system for actions pulls in appropriate cards for the slot. You have no control whatsoever over what they pick up. This isn't the worst thing, it means that you can't be totally invulnerable to investigators by misdirecting them over and over again. Where it hurts is when you have multiple actions on the board that will take the same items and if they get the wrong ones you lose. I want to specifically call out Fascination and Dread. These two cards are more or less the opposite to each other. Fascination generally represents losing yourself to the mania of the cult, where as Dread is depression and disillusion with the world. Fascination and dread both have timed actions associated with them that will consume cards which worsens if they get the same type and improves if they get the opposite, but again, you have no control over what magnet action takes the card. If you have both actions up at the same time, which is very common, you'll have to just hope that they go where you need because if they eat 3 cards it's a 60 second countdown until game over.For games with mods, I usually say you should play a few runs before you start using them. In the case of Cultist Simulator, I'd say you should play maybe a dozen or two runs before you start blatantly cheating. CTRL + ` (back tic) opens the console.

Cultist Simulator is a game that is endlessly fascinating. I can say I have never played anything quite like it. It took me nearly forty hours to attain my first standard victory but I was constantly engaged trying to solve its mysteries. It's really hard to get into what makes this game so engrossing without ruining its premise but I will at least let you know what it's not. With it having cards, different characters, and permanent death, it might be easy to think of this game as a roguelite but I assure you this is not that. I feel like it does the game a disservice to label it as such. Don't go in thinking of your various playthroughs as "runs" because it is simply not designed that way. The best analogy I can come up with to describe this game is that it's the language equivalent of a rubik's cube. The story is incredibly rich but it isn't told you in any conventional way. In fact, it's hard to even be certain that the information presented isn't just random esoteric scribblings but the more you read, the more you recognize. It's a game about timers, cards, and tiles; demanding you to keep track of a large amount of moving parts while being drip fed clues on how to proceed. My first playthrough ended unceremoniously as one would expect but my second ended because I lost sight on what I was really trying to achieve. What [i]are[/i] you trying to achieve? This is how the premise can confuse and torment you into thinking this could somehow not be a masterpiece. Look deeper, understand how it works, decipher everything you can. Even now, after only achieving a standard victory, I feel like there is more to discover and I can't wait to play again.

I do love this game, specifically for its evocative writing, and now that the team has made it so much less obtuse than it was at launch I think anyone who finds the aesthetic interesting can safely give it a shot and get something out of playing it. That said, it can be a frustrating trial and error experience especially when it comes to discovering and exploring the many vaults that the game uses as dungeons. For first timers, I would recommend keeping the vault page of the wiki up just for reference. Even with that help, this is a very time consuming idle game with many spinning plates that you'll need to keep in the air, and I can't see it being worth completing 100%% for anyone other than the most obsessed players. Completing a run is satisfying though, and it's a game that I am certain I will continue to return to periodically as I have over the past five years.

I love this game. It combines my love for Tarot, needlessly obscure mechanics, incomplete (and thus realistic) lore building, and the satisfaction of the hunt. Every card, no matter how mundane, is filled with Cioran-esque aphorisms and the broader design of the game makes you feel as if you're always one bad season away from losing and one good season away from victory. Cultist Simulator warrants a lot of the negative responses it gets, and is well worth dealing with all that. The game heavily, HEAVILY relies on your willingness to explore and experiment, which is fine, but like a lot of games that rely on combining items to solve puzzles, if you are not in rhythm with the games logic it's going to feel random. And, since it's a rogue-like, a lot of your runs will end in death and a restart, which can make it difficult to retain knowledge. Essentially, there are a lot of combinations you need to remember, and pairings of cards and actions you need to try, and it can be difficult to remember if you've explored a pairing, and what pairings did.;;That said, it's worth it. Most of the 'progress' you're going to make through the game is though your own understand of the game. The right thing to do is to examine everything. Read everything. Consider every combination that works. When you go to solve a problem, slot all of your cards and see what each one says. When something new happens, take note. When you need something, make sure you try every combination you have. All that helps immensely. Yes, there are easy ways to die, but there's also reliable ways to manage all of them.;;The next issue is that the game can take a long time if you're being careful and exploring everything. There's just a lot of possibilities, and if you're like me and want to focus on each thing, one at a time, to make sure you understand it, you're going to take a long time to get a playthrough. Granted, it's really cool. It took a long time to exhaust a particular story element, but I enjoyed it, and dedicated the time to complete it, and didn't feel disappointed when I did.;;Lastly, sometimes, you just don't want to learn the drop tables. This is my one major objection to the game. Some things you do alert you to the fact that there are no new possibilities. That's good. Some things don't. And some things are rare enough that you might do them 15 times and not realize there was a possible reward for them without googling it. It stinks, cause you just wouldn't know if you'd seen it all or not.;;Still, it's very well worth it. I love the tiny bits of lore. I love exploring new places and seeing what they have. I love amassing knowledge in a library of the esoteric, and probing further into the mythos. It's great, and you feel good when you pull it off. This post has been mostly warnings about the game, because that's easy to talk about. It's hard to explain how good it feels to get the next level of Knock, because until you are in the world, trying to glean the secrets of the Mansus, Knock means nothing to you. And I'm not going to spoil it.
Every time I play this game I learn something new I can do, or I learn a better way of doing something. It is a fantastic game if you like discovering and learning things in games you play.

I've played a lot of Cultist Sim now and I've enjoyed it greatly. This has been one of my favourites in the last few years and while probably not for everyone, I would recommend it to anyone to at least give it a try. My advice for any buyers of the game:;;- The game tells you to 'explore, take risks' and this is absolutely vital to enjoying the game. Slowly figuring out how to advance and not die gave me the warm and fuzzy feeling from puzzle solving. Don't just do the same things over and over trying to survive or the game will get frustrating.;- Don't be afraid to pause and consider your next move. Sometimes things can seem hopeless or stagnant while learning to play, but finding a creative solution to your predicament is very rewarding.;- Once you've settled in to things, READ. Alexis Kennedy is one of the best writers in gaming currently, and the lore is fascinating if you can get past the wordiness of the text. Conversely, if all you look for in games is fun mechanics then Cultist Sim will probably feel shallow. The occult ambience is what really makes this game great.;- While the wiki is very helpful and the lore is great, avoid it until you've learned pretty much everything you think you can. Figuring out all the different ways to reduce dread is much more rewarding than reading all of them in one go and not worrying about it ever again.;;With all that said, once you've figured everything out the game can get a little grindy and go on a bit too long while you try to complete it. At this point the lore is what makes continued play interesting. Recent updates have improved this somewhat.;;Overall this is a 9/10 from me and I'm hugely looking forward to The Book of Hours which will be releasing later this year. I've also just bought the TTRPG counterpart 'The Lady Afterwards' which looks great as well, and is a testament to my high view of the lore. Best of luck cultists!;

Cultist Simulator is an innovative and captivating game that offers a truly unique gameplay experience. The game is a combination of card game, strategy, and storytelling elements that come together to create an incredibly engaging and immersive experience.;;The graphics in Cultist Simulator are simple yet effective, with a minimalistic style that allows the gameplay to take center stage. The game's music and sound effects are also excellent, creating an eerie and atmospheric vibe that is perfect for the game's occult themes.;;What makes Cultist Simulator so special is its gameplay mechanics. The game is played through a series of cards that represent different actions and events in the game. Players must use these cards strategically to build their cult, gather followers, and perform rituals.;;The storytelling in Cultist Simulator is also superb. The game's narrative is told through a series of events and interactions that players must piece together to uncover the mystery of the game's world. The game also offers multiple endings, adding a layer of replayability that is rare in games of this type.;;The game's complexity can be intimidating at first, but it is ultimately rewarding. The sense of discovery and exploration as you unlock new cards and abilities is incredibly satisfying. The game is challenging, but it never feels unfair, and the learning curve is well-balanced.;;Finally, the game's community is incredibly active, with frequent updates and new content being added all the time. This ensures that there is always something new and exciting to discover in the game.;;Overall, Cultist Simulator is an exceptional game that offers a unique and engaging experience. With its innovative gameplay mechanics, excellent storytelling, and active community, it is a game that is sure to captivate players and keep them coming back for more.

Outstanding writing, world-building, sound design, and atmosphere. The unique and original world of Cultist Simulator stays on my mind even when I'm not playing. It's definitely not for you if you don't like reading, but if you do, even losing is a deeply rewarding experience as the game brings you to another soul adrift in the same strange, fascinating world.;;On that topic, I do think it's a BIT too hard. Most of the mechanics are explained in a conceptual, lore-based way, which is fun to read when you actually know what you're doing, but beginners might get overwhelmed by how impenetrable the game can be. I had about 15 tabs of the wiki open as I pursued my first minor victory, which I never would have achieved otherwise.;;Even so, I enjoyed every step along the way and didn't lose my enthusiasm for trying towards a major victory.

Oh man, Cultist Simulator? That game is trippy, especially when you're under the influence, if you know what I mean. As the Earl of Trash, I'm no stranger to indulging in a little recreational activity from time to time, and let me tell you, playing this game while in an altered state of mind takes it to a whole new level.;;The game is all about being a cultist and trying to uncover hidden knowledge, and let me tell you, when you're under the influence, it feels like you're really uncovering some secret truths about the universe. The visuals are so vivid and intense, and the soundtrack is like nothing I've ever heard before. It's like being transported to a different dimension altogether.;;Now, I will say that playing this game under the influence can be a bit disorienting at times. There are so many different elements to keep track of, and sometimes it can be hard to tell what's real and what's not. But that's all part of the fun, right? It's like being in a fever dream, trying to make sense of everything that's happening around you.;;And the best part? When you finally do figure something out, it feels like you've accomplished something truly meaningful. It's like you've unlocked some secret knowledge that nobody else knows. And that feeling is just incredible.;;So if you're feeling adventurous and want to try something new, I highly recommend playing Cultist Simulator while under the influence. Just be prepared for a wild ride, because this game is not for the faint of heart. But if you're up for the challenge, then let's get weird and dive headfirst into the world of cults and hidden knowledge. Let's see what we can uncover together, my friends.

Since everyone has a different taste I'll give you the positives and negatives and let you decide.;Positives - Amazing and interesting story that keeps you hooked until the end. The style is not unlike that of dark souls and elden ring, giving you a vast and interesting world, provided you don't mind reading. The music and ua are excellent. The art-style makes everything easily readable.;Negatives - Once you win the game once everything becomes trivial. All standard ascensions are almost the same i terms of progression. The DLCs are interesting and kind of innovative, unfortunately the base game is a boring never ending grind and the DLCs are an even bigger one. It is also a shame that you don't get new game+ for them as I am very curious about what we would need. But given this is a studio of 2 people I can forgive that. New game+ is very refreshing as here it isn't just a mindless repeat. There are unique requirements for winning each one and figuring them out is challenging. Exile further fixes the grind and adds randomness that makes the game rather thrilling and fun to just play.;Overall a great game if you don't mind reading and grindy, boring gameplay;Can't wait for Book of Hours

“灰机wiki”有详细注释，新手建议大概了解游戏机制（譬如作业，入梦，研究，谈话的功能性，这些内容很丰富，分支如消恐惧，邪名）再来玩，不然会死的不明不白，熟悉过后才是游戏开始精彩的部分。;;上手时间大概5H+以及阅读障碍者劝退，因为密教更像一部小说，需要你有一定的脑补能力和耐心，比起其他卡牌游戏（如杀戮尖塔，怪物火车，以目的性为主导的rouge）更像是点线面构成扁平化的极乐迪斯科，以飞升为目的确实是社畜模拟器lol（这个不是杀戮尖塔，喂= =），所以我想，这也是为什么新手引导的缺失（试玩了时之书发现也是如此），从一开始制作人便希望玩家能够仔细摸索品味他所搭建的世界并逐一展开，试错过后的正反馈本身就是游戏的一部分，有利有弊。;;游戏世界观较为复杂，原因在于碎片化的文本不容易让人串联，但叙事情感上非常细腻（文本真美，每一件物品都有其独特的注释），看似毫不相关的事件随着游戏的进展渐渐清晰（民俗学神秘学元素众多），似乎有种魔力让人继续探索下去。我并不会以第一人称视角代入，而是以上帝视角观察琉璃球中的另一个世界，或者说我本身就已经是这个游戏的全知全能，我只是在引导我的教徒们飞升。

I have spent so many hours on this game. A ridiculous amount. More than any other game in my library, in fact. And I still can't figure out what part of my brain it tickles or why, or how to recommend it to other people. I want more people to dive into and appreciate this universe, as it is so incredibly enthralling and mystifying that it deserves much more attention.;;I really wish I could recall how I started figuring things out and learning how to progress in the game. I definitely spent a lot of time on the Wiki. If you're an achievement whore, the multiple endings and legacies of this game are very satisfying to carry out, albeit with the help of said Wiki. And once I cleared a couple, I started opening the command console to better manipulate some things, and to figure out what they affect. Honestly I used the command console pretty liberally, after a certain point, to save scum a couple of the later diverging paths, but considering the sheer amount of content in this game and how many legitimate playthroughs I'd completed otherwise, I'm not that ashamed of it. If you have a love for collecting data, this game will probably hook you. ;;Wonderful and complex game, very hard to recommend. This game tells you there will be no tutorials to enhance the challenge. I'm going to tell you that this game is a logical labyrinth within which a minotaur awaits to tell you to commit non-living. I'm not even joking. During my playtime, the most common way for my playthroughs to end is from despair building up too quickly and without any easy way to remove it, naturally leading to my character ending their lifetime subscription to existence.;;This game has a large luck component for beginners. Maybe when you get 100+ hours you'll figure out how to buy anti-depressants, but after that I bet you'll have the complete inverse problem. Your character will start to see stuff, their mind will open too much and then they'll go crazy. I saw hints of that problem when I got past 4 hours with one character, but that was quickly resolved when my character played a thrilling game of knife tic-tac-toe on their wrists.;;When you do find yourself in a stable pattern, you'll quickly find that you're performing the same actions again and again, with no end in sight. Any form of experimentation is horribly dangerous to progression and can end your playthrough. If anything, it becomes a temptation simulator. How long can you go WITHOUT doing anything that would harm your progress?;;I refuse to use any online wiki tools to learn the game, because I feel as though that's cheating. The game wants me to play it by its own rules; No tutorials or hints. Just play the game and learn through playing. That would be OK if it didn't feel like the game was always waiting around the corner ready to rob you of all your progress.;;The worst part is I feel like I'm missing something from my playthroughs, some critical information which would make the game infinitely easier. I might come back to this game again someday to see if I can find out what it is, but that's a worse feeling after the experience I had than it would have been for any other game. Most games I stop and do something else and come back thinking "What about this?", but with this game all I can think is "What the heck am I supposed to do?".;;With the midgame grind and the borderline sociopathic difficulty wall, I cannot recommend that anyone play this game. It was a neat idea, but I feel as though the execution was poor. I couldn't recommend this game to my friends, and I couldn't recommend this game to anyone else unless you have no commitments for the next month to learn this game.

This is one of the best games in my library. I started playing it some years ago, dropped it, started again, then dropped it once more and then took the time to figure it out and got one of the many endings recently. There is perhaps two stages to this game: first when you are lost trying to understand it and is struck by a sense of wonder, mistery and discovery (especially if you read some esoteric literature before); then it comes a second level to the game, when you control the mechanics and fight your way to finish it. It can be an extremely frustrating experience at times, but rewarding as well. It is probably a faithful simulation of a cultist life, since you are dealing with your job, health, sanity and cult businesses at the same time. The soundtrack and sound effects are incredible. A hidden gem.

A forewarning that the game is INCREDIBLY hard.;;It's a roguelike card game and it basically tells you nothing.;;The game expects you to figure everything out on your own, what cards are used with what action, what combinations lead to what.;;Sure, you could probably look up a guide and have it all given to you, but the point of the game is figuring it out on your own. ;;The game even says to you first thing "explore, take risks", your cult leaders will likely die or get caught, you'll game over a lot, but from each character's failure, you take after another person following in their footsteps, and each character you play as changes the rules entirely.;;Personally, i'm terrible at the game, I still just can not beat it, but it's pretty fun;The level of branching paths, ways in which things can go, ways in which you can play is insane, but the trick is figuring those ways out for yourself;;All difficulties aside, I do highly recommend it, just be ready for some frustrations as you start off with absolutely no idea what you're doing.

What kind of game is Cult Simulator? Uh, I don't know.;It's definitely a card game, but you could probably never play it with physical cards. It would be more complicated than things like Gloomhaven and Aeons End. It's kind of like that though.;It's definitely a management game. I felt like I was spinning plates, trying to keep insanity, despair and the authorities from ruining everything while researching, working to make money, dreaming about... stuff and organising for my cult to go on tomb raids.;It's kind of a rogue-like. I'm sure you could probably do some save manipulation but it's not built into the game, so you'd be messing around with save files. Essentially, if you die, go mad, fall into despair or the authorities catch you, it's game over and you start again. However, there's definitely parts of your game that carry on when you win (which I've only done once because I'm secretly pretty bad at games) so it feels like you're telling a story.;Speaking of which, it's extremely lore-rich. The devs knocked it out of the park with Lovecraftian flavour. This game tastes like Cthulhu.;This game doesn't hold your hand. At. All. I am not ashamed to admit that I had a few cultist sim wiki pages open because damn, it's complicated and not at all obvious what you're supposed to do, although there are hints and the game is very intuitive. I would recommend you don't simply follow a guide to victory but don't feel bad if you need to look up how upgrading lore cards work.;;So, yes, this is a weird game. But it's addictive once you get the hang of it. You want a follower who is strong in Moth and writing manuscripts for patrons will make you rich as heck. Those are my two tips.;Have fun pulling off your flesh and existing within the Manus.

I acknowledge that the game advertises its lack of a tutorial as "part of the challenge" right on the store page, but the deliberately obtuse directions and total lack of clear objectives or indicators of progress are far too hostile to the beginning player. These issues, compounded with several others, collectively fail to create any incentive to explore many gameplay options or engage with the lore, which, to my understanding, almost universally receives high praise. Nearly every facet of this game is hurt by this.;;The gameplay cycle can really only be described as tedium; the initial phase of resource pooling at the start of a run does vary a little depending on the legacy you choose, but afterwards, every run proceeds the same for hours. The inconsistent durations of the action timers, as well as the intrusion of random actions, necessitate frequent pausing which really kills any sense of flow and can be particularly distracting when working towards larger goals. While it seems like this game does have an incredible depth to the mechanics and the choices necessary to acquire cards for the major win conditions, I find myself only making incremental discoveries with each subsequent run despite active attempts to try new things and only having played a handful of hours, which to me is a really bad omen of the time investment to come.;;The current user interface is very clunky. New cards tend to generate on top of other cards in the spawn frame, cards that should be stackable aren't, and the auto-stack option occasionally doesn't work. The lack of an automatic (or even user-defined) sorting system is criminal for a game like this, and attempting to relate card disorganisation to some narrative sense of chaos is kind of obnoxious. I cannot personally attribute praise to the overall narrative or the little flavour texts associated with each action and card as the time-sensitive gameplay cycle discourages paying attention to them, and I haven't quite developed a Stockholm syndrome brand of curiosity to actively seek them out. The art is pretty though, and the original soundtrack is quite good too, although the short tracklist doesn't help the sense of monotony.;;I'll probably still give it another chance or two, but I really cannot recommend this. It is frustrating to learn, and boring to play after that.;;Addendum: I think my previous assumption of a deeper lategame stage was a bit generous. While fulfilling the various win conditions does require fairly specific resources, the methods of obtaining them remain just as monotonous as the midgame. [spoiler]Farming Secret Histories via the Ways is a repetitive process, the Frangiclave tool is simply broken, lategame Vault Obstacles are no more difficult to overcome[/spoiler], etc. Acquiring the final few cards for a specific ending boils down to repeating these actions over and over again, with the whole process being artificially drawn out by [spoiler]Hunters, Illnesses, and other random actions that no longer pose as threats.[/spoiler];;The gameplay remains consistently tedious from start to finish, and there isn't really a sense of accomplishment after successfully beating a run. The overall execution of the game's ideas is disappointing, and I cannot recommend.

There are many flaws in the design that encourage players to get caught up into tedious, repetitive loops -- that then punish the player for being in said loop.;;You won't get any proper alerts. You won't get any warnings. You have a huge board to manage and repetitive tasks that you must partake in or not advance. You are going to just place the wrong card or repeat your last action (that you've repeated literally a 100 times) without thinking and screw yourself on a solution to something irreversible.;;If you love pain and being punished by the game cycle, as a rule -- play this. 30 hours in, I think I finally understand this game, but I don't think I'm having much fun playing it. The writing and worldbuilding are great, but everything about the game itself undercuts them: you have to keep zooming and scrolling around to read tiny text; most of the gameplay is just dragging cards from one location to another (no helpful shortcuts like "repeat action", almost no mechanical reason to pay attention to the story); you're either constantly mashing the pause button on double speed or sitting around bored on regular speed; the timer and the sheer repetitive grindiness encourages you to ignore the flavour text anyway. You can go from perfectly fine to game over in three minutes if you're not careful, and it's hard to stay careful when you're encouraged to just mindlessly continue the same actions. A really cool game could be made from this story, but this isn't it.
Oh, it's 5 AM again, and I have work tomorrow. AGAIN.

缺点：游戏前期和后期都称得上坐牢，前期没教程，后期重复度高。前期不知道恐惧入迷邪名咋消，很容易死。后期即使是DLC内容（除流亡者）也只是飞升部分方式不同，整体的培养和玩法基本上一致，都是：堆三维，找教徒，买书读书，入梦刷东西，探险。;其次是游戏中的随机性部分，游戏中大部分内容都做不到百分之百成功。我估计制作组是故意的，但是一方面如果考虑到极端脸黑一直失败真的很搞心态。出过很多次消证据连续失败3、4次然后邪名越堆越多。另一方面考虑后期探索，基本上都要过3道关，每道关即使数值堆满了成功率也是90%%，算下来就是有大于25%%的概率你可能会失败。这些关卡失败了的惩罚如果是消耗探索的金币重新再过一次还好，但是大部分都会受伤，要你赶紧治人或者加另外一个人去探险，还有一部分会给你诅咒，诅咒你不知道怎么整的话就只能白白被吃掉三维，就算知道该怎么整也相当麻烦。总而言之这个随机性部分没有给我留下多少惊喜，只有血压。;最后一些碎碎念：工作部分要一直点，重复性劳动。密传的升级太慢了，过一大堆无用的30s通悟部分，我觉得要么就拉长升级放素材的部分可以不那么容易就错过（经常去管别的东西就忘了这个升级然后又要浪费半天去重新过那一大堆30s的部分），要么就缩短那些没什么意义的部分。;最后说一些优点：游戏的文本部分太强了，同时整体成功塑造了一个密教探寻飞升之路的氛围。游戏的世界观也挺厉害的（虽然只看文本的话很难全部连在一起），BGM和美术也没拉跨，玩法在学会了怎么不玩死之后也有大概二三十小时的游戏体验不错的时期。
没做好心理准备不要打开，不要打开，不要打开！;真玩不明白，完全没有新手指引，所有的东西都需要自己摸索，偏偏这个世界观又非常庞大，各种卡牌排列组合，规则多且繁杂，剧情全是碎片，看得人一头雾水。;不能说它不好玩，但真的很累人！游戏里的我（赵四）狂热追寻未知的伟大存在，游戏外我又累又暴躁两眼一抹黑，那种神神叨叨的状态是相通的，赵四（本教主名讳外人不可直呼）飞升了，我发癫了，我们都有美好的未来。

The game is deliberately unhelpful to make you experiment  and I like when games force you to learn, but with Cultist Simulator this can be quite daunting.;;Basically if you prefer action games like me and were curious when you saw this game but have never played anything like it, know nothing about H.P Lovecraft and don't want to use the wiki / youtube guides for a few hours, give this a miss. Otherwise it's great and will definitely keep you coming back.

[b]In a nutshell:[/b];;Cultist Simulator is a beautiful, frustrating mess and a game of contradictions. It's a single player tabletop card game with a lot of depth and complexity, yet full of frustrations.;A niche title that will cater to a very limited audience.;;There is almost no hand-holding to speak of. Patience, tenacity, multitasking, planing ahead, and keeping track are necessary skills; requirements even. High tolerance to failing and starting over is very desirable to have.;;[b]The positives:[/b];;A game of deep mechanics, captivating world-building, compelling theme and setting. The music fits the mood and sets the atmosphere well. There is lots of lore and story to discover and unravel.;;Going in blind is the preferred way to experience the game. The game is at its best in the early stages. It's captivating to learn the intricate, deep and complex mechanics. The process of experimenting and mastering the mechanics is joyful and the peak of the game.;;If you get enthralled by the game and its world, it's easy to lose track of the time. The hours can slip by without your notice.;;[b]The negatives:[/b];;After the honeymoon phase, many of the game's shortcomings and design flaws come to light.;;The mid and late game can especially be a slow, grindy and frustrating slog. Ironically, for all it's complexity and possibilities, you're presented with limited endgame options. Expect to often be in the mercy of the RNG gods.;;The timers left a particularly bad impression. It's reminiscent of bad mobile game mechanics and it has little respect for your time. After a while, I found it more enjoyable to advance the time through the console. It would have likely worked better if the game was turn based instead.;;There is a distinct lack of options in regards to managing and utilizing your followers. Extra tokens for interactions with cult members and expeditions should be present. As it stands, there are too many things competing with talk and explore tokens.

This game commits to being purposefully obscure, to the point where it often feels like the core gameplay revolves around trial and error. The lack of clear instructions and stated relationships between gameplay mechanics results in a pointlessly obtuse game that does not reward the player with a result equivalent to the effort spent trying to decipher painfully specific combinations and events within the game. Due to the lack of a tutorial and any semblance of documentation on the part of the creators, be prepared to read through the fanmade wiki just to learn how to progress past the most basic of events. Then, prepare to spend more time on the wiki than in the game trying to figure out literally anything about how the game works. A very strong 'Do not recommend' from me.

I really can't make up my mind if I recommend this game or not. ;On the one hand: the lore is deep and intriguing, the feel is spot on for an impenetrable 1920s occult horror.;;On the other hand: this is a game you want to keep paused 90%% of the time, then run when you have everything in order. The mechanics can feel frustrating when too many things are triggered at once and experimenting is really tough, which makes learning new things about the game tricky without using a lot of your time. The colour coding on the cards is useful right up until there is too much overlap. ;;On the other other hand: The UI gets more complicated as you go which is thematically on point for having too many things happening at once, but visually difficult to keep track of if you're playing a game with the intention to enjoy yourself. Some events that trigger are difficult to see coming and have disastrous impacts on whatever progress you made this playthrough, again - thematically appropriate but irritating when trying to play organically. I ended up opening a wiki just to try and keep track of a few more things / make a bit more progress before needing to restart again.;;Ultimately I'm not sure I'll ever pick this up again because I don't know if I have the patience to play more games of patience. It feels like a game that I could enjoy on my tablet, but it's too unwieldy to play on my tablet, and I have more enticing things to play on my gaming machine.

As someone with ADHD, I am here to say that this game is an absolute nightmare for someone with ADHD to play but also that I unequivocally love it. There's an intriguing universe at work here, a setting that you can figure out through careful observation of the butterfly-effect ripples your actions cause... OR, you can charge blindly forth, doing whatever you want and learning nothing from the consequences of your actions because you can't remember which consequence is tied to which action! The latter play style actually got me farthest in the game because I didn't know enough to be cautious and took risks that I wasn't aware were risks... and got some unexpected payoffs. ;;The resource management aspect of the game is truly killer for people who aren't good at multi-tasking, but it also encourages you to take the initiative and forge ahead with a deadline looming over your head. In other words: the unknown  MIGHT kill you, but falling behind on rent? Will DEFINITELY kill you.;;I for one am fully willing to turn myself into a whole-ass other creature in order to avoid paying rent, which is actually what one plotline in this game is totally about!

Something keeps drawing me back to this game. The setting, the learn-by-doing game mechanics, card driven actions... But as I'm playing it, I'm constantly just waiting for that "reward" after hours of immense grindyness of this game. Some greater game mechanic breakthrough. Just something that makes all my failed runs and literal waiting amount to something.;;But in the end, I feel like I'm just flipping sand timers to upgrade numbers on cards I don't understand what do. The game wants me to experiment, but some experiments will end your run (death) after hours of grinding, forcing you to restart and repeat your previous grindings with not much in the way of new variable content. Each run is so incredibly long and repetitive that it really dissuades you from wanting to try out stuff fearing that you will have to do all this waiting again.;;In the end, I'm fascinated by the premise of the game, but it never seems to deliver... anything? Except making me feel stupid.

好题材，糟玩法，游戏的内容与游戏的玩法间缺乏联系。完全缺失的指引让本就晦涩的游戏变成了摸石头过河的开盲盒。需要收集的前置卡牌取决于完全随机的产出，而且种类过多，导致的游戏过程就是在一遍又一遍的刷卡，合成，流程极其冗长，缺乏的正反馈更是让游玩过程堪称折磨。;剧情仅仅只是一个开头的引子，在大部分的时候，剧情非常割裂，我无法从繁多的卡牌中得到什么有象征意味的主题或者寓意，卡牌充满着对神秘学知识的挪用但却没有进一步的拓展，也没有融合进玩法中，玩家只是拿着不知所云的卡牌堆成一排，然后拖进槽内等时间慢慢流逝。;策略方面也捉襟见肘，生存压力小，只需要重复工作便可以免去因为时间而导致的死亡，往往做出行动的依据不是“我想做什么”而是“我能做什么”，说白了就是被随机分配的卡牌牵着鼻子走。;即便是本就晦涩的神秘学的题材也没法为这些游戏性上的缺陷做出辩解，这是一个缺乏打磨的卡牌肉鸽游戏，买前请慎重。

I’ve had this game for a while now, and I’m offering this review from the perspective of someone who played it, put it down for a while, and then came back to it. When I picked it up again, I quickly remembered why I had stopped playing it to begin with. The short version- if you like micromanaging, keeping an eye on the timer, don’t mind having to restart regularly, and have a lot of time and patience to wait for the results you want, you might enjoy this game. If not, I would seek entertainment elsewhere.;;Now for the long version. There are some things about this game that I truly do enjoy. The worldbuilding, lore and writing are all absolutely wonderful. Everything is written in a very elegant and imaginative way, and it drew me in very quickly to what might be going on in this created world. It also had a lot of surprises- the first time I entered the Mansus via dreams it was completely accidental and I was stunned by my new discovery. There are a lot of little secrets you can uncover throughout the game, and I did enjoy that part. In addition, although the learning curve is somewhat steep (which the game made clear up front), the basic mechanics of putting the right card with the right action to get results, was very easy to pick up.;;However, my enjoyment was eventually swept away with the boredom and frustration I felt as the game progressed. I expected some level of frustration, given the warning going into the game. However I didn’t expect it to be as much of a slog as it was. It can take ages to get the cards you want and need to progress, and then sometimes you have to take those cards and mix them with other things to get the other cards you need, but you have to collect things for THAT, and it can take ages… you get the idea. And the whole time you have events with timers going off that you HAVE to keep track of or you will lose the game. And sometimes, despite your best efforts, you can’t get the cards you need when you need them, and you quickly find yourself at a game over screen, so you have to start from scratch with another character. At one point, aside from the Time and Job timers, I had not one, but TWO Dread events, Fascination, Hunter, Lover, some other event I can’t remember now, and this was on top of an expedition I was dealing with. It was a lot- too much, especially since it’s completely random and there’s no limit to how many you can get at once.;;My final straw this time came when I had a timer countdown for Fascination- if you get three and can’t cancel it out with Dread or Fleeting memory, it’s Game Over. The only way to get Dread aside from some random events, is to Dream with Reason. However, I got everything BUT Dread when I did that, and of course eventually the timer ran out. At this point, I had collected almost every location you can travel to, all my Followers were at Disciple level, and I had a lot of lore that I’d been building up. And this was the third time this had happened, where despite my best efforts and keeping an eye out and doing everything I could to prevent it from happening, I got a game over. Maybe eventually I’ll forget about the frustration and anger this game inspired in me and will want to try again, but I doubt the third time picking this game up will be any different than the first two.;

It's almost an okay game, but falls short in my opinion.;The driving mechanic of the game is getting semi-random cards to use for various tasks. Both the cards and tasks have timers. But you can pause and unpause as you like. This feels unnecessary and clumsy. Nor are they labeled in a way that makes their role easily identifiable. Maybe if there was a tutorial explaining anything. You can click on empty card slots within actions and cards that can be used will be highlighted. Though a few situations I filled all required boxes in an action but the game wouldn't let me start it and didn't offer an explanation.;;The story seems alright, just not good enough to plod through the gameplay.

This review is as spoiler free as possible.;;The idea behind Cultist Simulator is pretty interesting:;Play a complex card game without knowing the rules, learn from failure and start with a slightly different approach in the next round.  ;Quite frankly, that idea gets ruined by its execution which is just a time wasting exercise in frustration. My main gripe, aside from technical problems, are the timers that frequently ruin an attempt at experimenting with a rule you think you understand. For example: ;Cards sitting on a short 60 second timer, that get grabbed and deleted when another 60 second timer rolls the wrong event, so you have to start a whole chain of preparations again, some of those with random outcomes.;;On the other hand the game consistently fails to produce a proper "fail state". After loosing my first two attempts pretty quickly to mechanics i had no clue about, the next 12 hours where spend on one attempt at winning. I would have loved to start again after actually loosing, but managing the "real" fail states is surprisingly easy when you know the rules of them and all you are left with is the failed timer events that throw a wrench in your attempts at experimenting with the cult.;Additionally in my experience one particular "verb" is extremely overused in generating new cards and much of the playtime was spent waiting for said "verb" to be freed up again.;;Then there are the technical problems, like cards not being stackable suddenly, events that reset the view of the table and the general ease of misclicking cards or UI elements.;;The sounddesign is mostly functional with pretty good music that gets repeated to much and sometimes cuts off in the middle of the track.;;The game shines then in its writing, pretty much as expected from looking at the lead writers previous works. The atmosphere around creating your cult is great and pretty much the only thing that kept me going for this long.;;In the end I'm left with the frustration that I would very much like to continue playing, if it only would respect my time in return.

非常希望以後還能有新作...印象中我的頭像是每次都幫我修鏡子的小夥子。;都已經2022年了，我還在想念這款遊戲;很懷念通宵打他過去的那些歲月;二周目門檻過高，打了兩次，分別是杯教跟燈教都打不過;一周目的部分，個人覺得鑄教的門檻確實最低。杯教略難於燈教（要想辦法一直殺人可是又不能引起調查）;新手的話三大教可能還是鑄教入手比較方便，我自己三到四小時左右能通，網路上三十分鐘速通的影片太多了就不具體說了。;然後跟教徒戀愛的部分，好是好在如果有升高級教徒，之後飛升可以拿來獻祭，而且我印象中他是可以被繼承到二周目用的。;壞就壞在如果曾經頂鍋坐牢，之後直接叛變另立門戶，或者去找寶藏的時候堵門搶路特麻煩（巡警頓悟也是一樣，寧可殺了或關起來，也別讓他們開始修仙）。;所以我個人是覺得可以有高級教徒，但是不要當愛人，或是愛人別當高級教徒......反正高級召喚物很多，後期都很好出的。;結論是：這遊戲真的很好玩，設定特別棒，尤其是漫宿、司辰的設定。;有空玩的人記得去看灰機wiki，那裏寫的設定都很詳細。;書的部分都記得看內容，這遊戲具體玩的方式是很枯燥、重複的，第二輪的容錯率更低，我玩杯教一下子就暴斃，燈教還撐了一陣子。;最好玩的部分在於每個教具體如何飛升，裡頭的教徒如何用神秘的方式供養教主云云。;尤其杯教那種食人癖我不是很理解，我最喜歡的司辰也不是杯教的。;要說這是克式的美學我也並不是特別贊同，相差有些距離，但是尤其地引人入勝。

“林地生长于漫宿墙外。每一个研习诸史的人都知道，漫宿无墙。”;手机上玩了几百小时的盗版特来补票。;虽说游戏名字起得实属掉价，但游戏中的文本属实惊艳到我。不止是玄而又玄，神秘诡异的部分。就算是对每个角色感情戏的寥寥数笔也令人印象颇深。高中交读书笔记时我抄写的是这游戏的文案，文本在这里不止是理解的工具，其本身就成了一门艺术。再加之其庞大，神秘而又完善的世界观，在图书馆嚼几个小时也不足为过。;如果是作为小说，那无疑是当之无愧的精品。作为游戏呢，游戏性就见仁见智了。叙事类卡牌，本身就没多少操作，只有探索和文本的乐趣。新手阶段一脸懵。别说带来拂晓了，要在城里苟活都难，因健康而死，因绝望而死，被”残阳“带走。虽说探索也是这个游戏的乐趣之一，但不可否认的是，确实缺乏新手指引。要想真的弄明白大部分牌能干嘛，各种情况怎么处理，恐怕需要六七十小时的游戏时长，即便如此，有时候还是需要查wiki。大致熟练之后就进入这个游戏最有乐趣的时期，不必担心生存的探索期。从林地到孔雀之门都逛一遍，从首都到午港都去探索，男的女的都约去褪衣俱乐部看看反应，各种仪式都试一试。最后凑够相应的相性，快乐飞升。;但在这之后呢？重开的前期又是痛苦的，三个属性的技能得重新升，教徒得重新召集，看过的书也得重买。这段时间是乏味的，重复的。再精通一点，你确切知道每个藏宝地的物品，每个仪式会带来什么，读每本书能知道什么，就已经失去了大部分乐趣，况且游戏的随机性并不高。当然，玩到这一步并不容易，它的体量并不小。不过现在看着自己几百金，全密传，全工具的档，飞升都未必比现在有意思。为什么只有一个档呀，这点实在是扣分项。一局的时长对于有工作的人来说大概也需要一周。;总的来说，这是一款瑕不掩瑜的好作品，它的体量与文本足够你很长时间沉浸其中，也值得了解和回味。如果你喜欢它的文风与世界观，如果你喜欢叙事类卡牌，无疑是值得入手的。;于我而言，”我誓将己身献出，为愿者，也为不愿者点亮路途。我将踏上已显现的路途，无论代价为何。”;

As a fan of esoteric occult stuff and H.P. Lovecraft, I love the vibe of this game! Game play can be challenging and grindy at times, but the flavor text and setting is inspired. Personally, I also appreciate the fact that the game doesn't hold your hand---half the fun is learning how the game works as you play it. I've put a lot of hours into this game and I STILL suck at it, but I've always enjoyed playing, even when I die (which is often, lol). Would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a different kind of management game, especially if you're a Lovecraft fan!

[h1]总结：非常好的游戏，可惜……[/h1];[h1]推荐人群：肉鸽游戏爱好者，赌狗，以及所有热爱游戏不确定性的人[/h1];;;[h1]优点[/h1];1，[b]丰富的内容[/b]：真的非常非常喜欢《密教》的世界观设定，包括神明体系，飞升体系，欲望等等，还有每一个赞助商，后期靠文字养活自己简直是理想生活，所以说教主都有这个能耐了，为啥不去开个公司【笑】;;2，[b]万事皆有出路，只要你不贪心[/b]：这里我愿不害臊地分享我放弃游玩的原因：[spoiler] 因为作弊导致坏档，我中了一个干涸诅咒，而且吸了我理智，且我没有心影响消除它，为了保住理智我尝试回档，结果就坏档了，太可惜了，是马上就要铸飞升的档，坩埚王都召唤出来了，10等级使徒也有了，就差一个神器[/spoiler];;3，[b]游玩方式多样[/b]：我本来还是很期待玩蛾、心、冬、灯、杯飞升的;;;;[h1]缺点和不推荐人群[/h1];如果你的人生本来就被其他因素所控制，使得你根本无法掌控自己的命运，那我甚至不推荐你玩任何肉鸽游戏。;我很羡慕那些敢于面对游戏中困境的人，他们似乎很容易相信制作者不会辜负他们，游戏中的一切皆有解答，以及，他们一定能胜利。;但，这很显然不是每个人都能做到的：当游戏失控的时候，我仍希望通过手段来扭转现状，就像面对过往那些失控的问题一样，希望有神一样的魔法可以让自己得到帮助（而不是相信别人，或者相信自己）;很显然，这恰好是《密教》的核心玩法之一。;;所以，真的很遗憾，《密教》是个好游戏，但不适合我。;这也是我的第一篇steam游戏评测，希望够真诚。

补票来的，所以时长很短;一开始很难上手，但只要知道几个小技巧，一切就变得简单起来。;文案写的好棒，翻译的也很有味道，游戏里塑造的世界是最令我着迷的世界观之一。;也买了无光之海，收藏了图书馆，希望这两部作品以后都可以出很棒的汉化（毕竟我的英语水平实在是太糟糕了）;;以及，守夜人！！！我是你的狗！！!嗷呜呜呜~~~;（飞升漫宿）;（变成杯长生）;（疯狂试图追奉守夜人）;（被嫌弃）;（天天跑到刀刃阶梯嚎叫）（蠕动）;（被打入虚界）（爬上来）;（坚持扭曲，蠕动，爬行，嚎叫）

This one is recommended, albeit with some stark caveats. The whole point of this game is actually figuring out how to play. You learn about the world presented and its rules, and how to manipulate them to your own ends, bit by bit, usually by trial-and-error or even pure accident, At the start this is mostly a matter of figuring out how to keep your belly full while also scraping up enough spare change to buy books, but later on the "roguelike" nature of the game can become a painstaking drag as you risk death while trying to work out a difficult and convoluted ascension sequence. I enjoyed the world, the implied stories, and the "tidy up an increasingly cluttered desktop" aspects enough to keep playing, but only with the help of a bit of save-scumming (literally saving copies of the savegame file to reload as necessary) that cut down on, most likely, literally hours of repetitive work.

The flavour, ambience and artistic presentation are excellent. It captures very well the sense of rationalist magic, where even the gods can be compelled to serve given enough knowledge and planning. There aren't many graphics that are individually impressive, although the chart of the Manus is quite good.;;The UI, with its skeuomorphic presentation of virtual cards, is quite clever, but breaks down in the later game when many cards are in play. One needs to spend time regularly tidying the playing space. If a vital card seems to have been snatched away for no reason, the game may have drawn it under something else, waiting for you to dig it out. Or it may actually have destroyed something you needed, but typically that only happens for things you can replace. The game proceeds in real time, but is pausable. I like to switch between fast worward and paused; I don't use "niormal speed" much.;;The game is very grindy. Expect 40+ hours to work out how to win, and then 10+ hours to drive it to a standard, major victory. The working-it-out time can be reduced by reading the player-compiled wiki, but this is a massive list of spoilers and using it degrades the core of the game which is the character's growing understanding of the lore and background. The lore and the ways of winning are supposed to be cryptic. Unfortunately, the UI mechanics are similarly cryptic and sometimes one needs the wiki to find out how to do something that would be obvious to the character. If you like learning by failing and retrying, then this game will be a treasure for you.;;There are multiple, major victories, so the game is highly replayable. Some of the endings are specific to character classes, and some classes are only playable after achieving certain endings. Some are only available when using paid-for DLC. However, there are interesting aspects of the game that are available for free, but only playable after winning a standard, major victory, so I recommend getting to that stage before reaching for the DLC.

I thought I'd enjoy the game but it's just not for me. I'm all for wasting time but its not like there's even any fun to it, the game just goes in circles on and on SLOWLY accumulating wealth and stats, and bogging you down with "Seasonal" stuff that you can't develop any real counter to unless you change the values of warmups and lifetimes of, in the game files themselves, to keep some sanity you'd lose playing this game.;;Everything takes forever to do, taking up valuable time and usually action tiles you NEED to counter something right this second. There's loads of attributes or stats on all the cards that give you some sense that there's some deeper meaning or lore to the game, and there is, but good luck ever getting there by the time your grandkids are born. God forbid you die, which is likely to happen given the consistent depression you go into, or blind insanity.;;I tried playing the dancer, I was actually interested in this weird evolution ordeal. Then the save got corrupted cuz of an update. Fantastic, I'm back to an Aspirant being a Glover and Glover bootlicker. I guess you're supposed to accumulate this lore after spending Funds at a book store, studying them and dreaming in The Wood for chances at getting cards that might do something if you're lucky, and this lore helps your "Cult" that will fail somehow? Notoriety stacks like crazy and if you dare do ANYTHING you'll generate it constantly, so you're bound to fail anyway.;;There's no... direction. There's no point. I'm trapped farming gold for Glover and Glover, not doing anything with my Cult because some Detective either constantly sticks nothing at me when I do nothing with zero evidence, or has a field day with existing Notoriety because I wanted to make a contact, running circles in The Woods expecting a different outcome, and collecting Lore that I'll lose because no shit. This taking HOURS to do, by the way. I get that there's no tutorial, I get this is a trial and error game, but when the trials take a good 4 hours of my time to get any significant progress (and accumulation of stats and lore doesn't feel like it) and the errors are attempting to do so in any capacity whatsoever, it just feels like a shallow game that acts like its super deep.;;Magnetism happening at the very start of a tile's spawn/cycle is a travesty. Whats that? You're down to your last coin and your Dream tile is almost done, and you need to spend money on sleeping because your character has 4 different despair cards and will kill themselves if they don't get a smidgen of happiness? Oops, Time card's done, consuming its previous already stored coin. It'll just steal that out of your hands thank you very much you're dead now. You could have gotten the Funds from your job, if you had that 20 seconds of depression covered from spending 10 seconds sleeping with your money. By the way, as a "reaction" to despair, it takes forever to do. ;;The game feels slow, the game feels obtuse and clunky. And it sure as shit doesn't feel fun. Go watch playthroughs, or go read up on the lore on a wiki, it'll save you the headache of playing this game. Why don't I look up a tutorial for this game? Well you see, having to watch a person spend 4 hours avoiding the frustrations of this game just to get a step further than you is even more exhausting than doing it manually.

A game that doesn't hold your hand, Cultist Simulator not just encourages, but requires exploration and trying new things. With essentially no tutorial, expect to perish quite a bit until you figure out the general game flow. Primarily text based, you figure out your next step through puzzling over the lore of the cards (or if you're cheeky by checking the wiki). This is a game that WILL punish failure and poor resource management, but it will also reward critical thinking and logical inference. With interesting lore and captivating writing, this is a game will initially frustrate but captivate you, and after your first "a ha!" moment you'll be hooked for hours to come.

This is a weird one, I can recommend the game despite bouncing off it.;;[i]Cultist Simulator[/i] takes the 90s game design decision of no tutorial/learn as you go and dials it up to 11. It often feels directionless and confusing, but it does it intentionally. The writing and atmosphere are top notch and will be appreciated by anyone even vaguely interested in cosmic horror.;;The gameplay itself is largely narrative driven, with any time pressure being alleviated by simply pausing. It feels like a visual novel met the real time strategy genre.;;Ultimately [i]Cultist Simulator[/i] is... weird. I can't say for sure whether it's for you since it does not have mass appeal, but it is worth trying out since if you like it, you will love it.

纵观游戏发展，有一个明显的趋势是越来越注重“探索”两个字，大家都在往这个方面，在题材或玩法上进行着或多或少地尝试。其中，《密教》是最令我可惜的作品，离神作就差那么一步之遥。它完全放弃了引导与教程，激进地把“探索”两个字作为游戏核心玩法，以换来令人入迷的初见体验。“每一个研习诸史的人都知道，漫宿无墙。”直面风险，探索前行。你不会总是能够得知下一步该做什么。不断尝试吧。”这是你进入游戏最先看到的两句话。宏大，诡异又诱人的世界观，庞大的文本量，使玩家真正带入进去，战战兢兢，又难以自拔地从浩如烟海的书籍遗物发掘着被掩埋的历史和司辰与永生的秘密。性向，司辰，和某些设定、文本都耐人寻味，如“纷争正是这个世界的引擎”；“被赤杯饮尽的浪潮，被铸炉粉碎的燧石”，都让人浮想联翩。可成也萧何，败也萧何。把“探索”作为核心玩法使人初见时惊为天人，但多周目游玩时，玩家已摸清了设定与玩法，没有了开始时有趣的探索，就会产生大量无意义的重复劳动，使人感到疲倦。可《密教》本身偏偏是个多周目多结局的游戏，如果追求多结局或者全成就，这个问题相当致命。而最令我不解的是，AK当年是参与过《无光之海》制作的，重复度高这个问题本不该是个问题。仿照《无光之海》的继承系统，如果让教主每次胜利后，下一任教主能够继承部分教徒（熟人），或是某个低级密转或遗物，都能使这个问题得到完美解决，使《密教》成为当之无愧的神作，这难免让人遗憾。

《密教模拟器》在我这里最出彩的甚至不是游戏机制本身，而是它出色的文本，无论是原文还是译文。;;鉴于Alexis Kennedy是Stellaris时之螶事件链的外包作者，文本本身的高质量不足为奇。而中文译者显然是花了很大功夫去精心雕琢，不仅做到了锦上添花，使其更具神秘学色彩，还增强了独特的艺术性，以至于在该游戏的贴吧内都流行起了模拟密教文风的浪潮。我常常在阅读文本时惊叹于他们的巧思。;;每个密传对应的文风各不相同，譬如「冬」最具静默淡泊的美感，而「启」显然是仿照了圣经的风格。我个人最偏爱「蛾」的文本（本质蛾人XD），如晋升信徒时的——“时而剪子，时而小刀。时而为树，时而为骨。时而是月之振翅，时而是魂之生斑。他曾是血，而我们也将和他一样。”（'Now the scissors, and then the knife. Now the wood, and then the bones. Now the flutter of the moon, and then the dappling of the soul. He was blood, and so will we be.'）。以及有翼人偶的——“白骨屋上的阁楼有扇窗子。窗子旁边有个盒子。盒子里面有卷绷带。绷带里面有团乱发。乱发里面缠着只人偶，因为窗户从未打开过。”……这样一种极其微妙的混乱感，令人着迷。（入迷+1）;;回到游戏本身，一款非常适合强迫症的桌面整理模拟器。流程可长可短，取决于想苟多久。如果有耐心为了闪刃教会攒刃密传的话，那后期直接无敌，一刀一个警探杀穿防剿局，伦敦兄弟会了属于是。;;玩久了觉得流程有些重复，希望早出新dlc，顺便期待下日后的司辰之书。

I really wanted to like this game, it was hard to decide wether to give a thumbs up or down. In the end I have to choose based on the number of likes it has, just to balance it. ;In the beginning, the game is truly fascinating - the mystery, the writing, the cool unique gameplay, you are eager to find out what comes next and find yourself playing for hours, dying now and then. Well, once you figure out the card combinations and what you have to do, the game becomes extremely repetitive and frustrating. Once you place a card somewhere you shouldn't, you cannot cancel the timer and have it back. Once you fail (and there are tons of ways to fail), you cannot go back to a previous "saved game", you have to start from scratch, the entire process, all over again. I like the comparison with solitaire, except that here the game from start to finish is extremely long. One mistake, and all that work and progress goes down the drain, and you have to start all over again. Fun, right?;I didn't even start about the game interface and the "snap boxes" where the cards go in. To play this game well, you should organize your cards in a logical way, and that is part of the fun I guess, but that is impossible to keep up as the game just spits out new cards wherever it wants. At least half of the time you spend on pause just rearranging your cards, cause the game just spits them out all over the place. ;All in all, I would say its a very cool unique game that needs some tweaking. I 100%% agree with what someone here said, it would be considerably less annoying if you could set up "auto" functions for repetitive tasks - e.g. the "work" box, and define where which card type goes (e.g. I would've loved it if the game placed the new card in the same spot where I last left that type of card). Easy access to previous saves would also be a much needed feature.

Eh. It'd pass if I were you. ;;It's whack-a-mole with a Chuthlu skin.;;The stories on the cards are interesting, but par for course in the genre.;;What you get and have to deal with feels pretty random. There's some key places (research/studying) that seem purposefully slow in a weird way, compared to other actions, especially given how it's what you usually want to be doing. Resources are time based, and it's not always clear which ones you're going to need for something, or exactly when, so it can be frustrating as you can't actually just plan and build up and do something. It feels like pinball. ;;Example, you don't use "reason" to smush together the influences, you use "erudition", which comes from studying reason. But, smushing together the influences is also done via studying, so if you didn't happen to plan to have erudition on hand (which decays). But maybe, sometimes, you don't need "erudition", you need "Glimmering" instead. Maybe the wiki would help?;;There's tags in the game that help you understand what things are, and are used for smushing items together, but they're not 100%% reliable in terms of "This slot takes the foo tag", because they only usually take the foo tag. Putting something in a spot that it's not supposed to go throws it back on the board and throws an big annoying error. ;;You can click a slot and it will highlight cards it accepts (based on tag), but it literally won't actually accept all the cards it highlights.;;When cards come back down, they come back down stacked, sometimes, sometimes they go to some other place on the board. ;;Cards are allowed to be placed on top of each other, or half on top of each other. ;;Because things decay (or become un-tapped) at different rates, items that are the same but have different remaining lifetimes can't be stacked. So, lots of detritus in the game. ;;I guess it's on-brand in a cosmic horror game to not be sure and time to be against you (especially if you don't just keep the wiki open in the alt tab and have the game paused a lot), but it's just not fun.

As a fan of card games, Lovecraftian writing, and themes of the occult, this will always be one of the my favorite games of all time. Cultist Simulator won't hold your hand or dumb anything down, It forces you to assume the role you are given, as a scholar, a historian, and a seeker, and will reward you when you play it well.;;And if you do decide to give it a try, go into it blind. I can understand why people like this game. It has a great atmosphere at the start, with lots of exploration and "what does this do?" and stumbling onto lore and a real sense of progression inherent in the cycle of raising health/passion/reason. The writing of the descriptions are great, and the ethos behind the whole thing is fascinating.;;But none of that can overcome the game's single, most glaring flaw, and that is the sheer, incredible amounts of grind.;;Everything you do is on a timer. You put a card into an action platter, and then it counts down a timer until the results are in. Sometimes that timer results in needing to put another card into the platter or it fails out. You're not allowed to cancel anything - so other things might expire. If you haven't taken an action to get a card you need to succeed, you're SoL for that attempt, because usually the action needed for it is the same one you need to put it in.;;Actions take on the order of 30 seconds to 5 minutes to resolve, depending on which ones they are. The average is 60 seconds, one full minute. When everything is going, you're left staring at the counters counting down, waiting for the "time passes" timer to throw something at you.;;After the first few hours, once you get a feel for the game's rhythm and have read the various bits of description, the tension that the timers bring gives way to tedium. The novelty of the esoteric bits wears off. Going mad from revelations simply ends your game, rather than giving you more interesting things to do.;;Ultimately, the good points of this game are interesting when they are new, but as soon as the novelty wears off, it turns into "spinning plates simulator." Maybe that's fun for some people ... but for me, it's not.

I like the game's art style and lore and narrative told through the card descriptions. I just have -no- idea what I'm doing.  The game provides little to no direction.  You're often just combining cards hoping something will happen, and then you eventually get overwhelmed with the number of cards.;;The game really needs some checkpoints or structure explaining what your next goal should be, or some measure of progress.

The Game is certainly an acquired  taste whether you like the micromanagement aspect, the sorting of cards, the unique mechanics or simply the really diverse lore of the game, Cultist Simulator is probably one of my favourite games of all time.;;The Game hits so many niche interests I have and was found during a time where a I really enjoyed the works of HP Lovecraft and other Media that draws inspiration from it, and of course this game does so without cheaply using any creature from his short stories to draw a crowd and instead uses the ideas and themes of them, most notably the use of Cults, Forbidden Knowledge, Non-Euclidean shapes and structures, Delving too far, Madness and The Occult of course.;;The lore is so unique and diverse that i barely know where to start and of course i won't as i would only confuse myself, The Eldritch Creatures and beings feel awesome and unique, The Items descriptions are brief, weird and scream for more context in a way that gives you chills my personal favourite Being:;The Frangiclave (The art shows it as a purple key or lock-pick);"There are keys that open doors; then there are keys that destroy them.";;The existence of such an object is strange, and I personally like to imagine it as a kind of wand which tears apart reality fundamental opening anything, and of course I use it as such in DND games i host.;;The dialogue and flavour text of events feels smart and well written and passion can really be felt in each line and sentence made to either confuse you or entice you further although you can do what I did in my first play-through's and skip all text and simply work it out yourself by shoving cards into slots to see what happens caring only for results and not the means of them, and weirdly enough it can work as you find shortcuts and means to create desired cards for example the first main obstacle a player may find is managing Dread and money as every 60 seconds you lose 1 coin, once you have a job steadily running this no longer becomes an issue although your character becomes restless from the monotony of a boring life void of Esoteric matters and this restlessness breeds dread which can build up enough to kill your character, its only counter (at the start) being contentment which you learn to create through many different means but thats just dread there are many other things that need to be managed and kept at bay which can be stressful or personally really rewarding;;can't be effed writing the rest;the game is literally about sorting a table what more do you want in life???
