I have sunk DAYS into this game. I would say weeks, but I only spent 1.7 weeks total playing it. I have legitimately done all achievements, mastered all mysteries of the game and can pretty much flawlessly take anything from start to finish without an issue. It's a solid game with a lot of replayability.;;First of all... the atmosphere and art are great... simple, but subtle, really giving the vibe of the small danger you are at all times and the mysteries you approach. The minimalistic art and obtuse (but accurate) descriptions all serve the point of the game that it's supposed to be hard to approach. Every bit of progress feels like a celebration, especially when you break through into another phase of the game. Discovery is the experience it peddles and it can be a rush. Though I instead love the whole lore and book collecting angle for which I am thankful that the next game will be JUST THAT.;;Cultist Simulator is a game that you can take at your pace, from any angle, allowing plenty of options for victory, defeat and discovery. One might say "there are no wrong moves, just the wrong time for them". While in the beginning you will be walking around with no idea what you do, late game you will be casually throwing around mystical forces against things that man does not want to know exist. Your first run might fail horribly to one of the most basic issues. Your second run might be more long lasting. But eventually you will get that first victory and you will approach the ability to just do them one after the other... and start really seeing what the game has for you.;;Also, I do love the Exile DLC for really being a change from the usual style, offered a lot of world building and a lot of perspective. I do hope to see more into this world.

Been playing a *lot* of Cultist Simulator lately, it's a really great game.;I've been a huge fan of Alexis Kennedy's work for like a decade, since Fallen London and Sunless Sea. While I adored Sunless Skies despite his departure from Failbetter Games, him starting his own, new work has been a massive win. He's created this new setting in a markedly different way which is summed up in the title of his current series of books--*Against Worldbuilding*, which is deliberately provocative but if you've played his old works you can see what it's about.;The Fallen London story is immense and difficult to grasp, it's extremely intricate and detailed and spans several years of additions to a text-based browser game as well as some full-length PC games; it requires deep digging and exploration to find. It's great in its own right, and I don't think anything in the medium of video games really compares to the infamous quest "Seeking Mr Eaten's Name.";But whereas Fallen London and the Sunless games were written as long-form works of prose, and are interacted with through paragraphs and dialogue, Cultist Sim is a card game. For all its wonderfully creative cosmology and intrigue, it's all told in snippets, in flavor text, and the single-sentence descriptions of cards. The emphasis is on themes and recurring keywords; you grasp at the setting the same way your in-game character does--finding an old Greek or Latin text with a singular mention of "The Wood" or and odd-but-intentional reference to "The Three-Valved Door" in a 15th century French Drama.;It feels as rich and mysterious as the Fallen London games, but is imminently more readable and digestible. I can't call it strictly better--I don't think Cultist Sim could ever make me laugh or cry quite as much as the other games did. But the card game style of storytelling *really* tickles the internet paranormal researcher fancy.
I think my hours says it all, no?

The only good things about this game are its variety, story depth, and visuals. Gameplay is unbearable as you have to micromanage literally everything if you want to win.;;An unnecessarily long time sink because the time cycles are minutes long and the speed up function is minimal. Progression is hard capped as RNG is ridiculously bad, giving despair repeatedly despite any attempts at gaining contentment from drugs, resting, going to the club, or reviewing happy memories. The stupid amount of restlessness given rolls over to despair too. No real explanation as you smash together whatever will work for hours on end just to realize the specific rites you needed to progress won't proc and you're left with a damnable amalgamation covering your entire board. Smash your keyboard when you realize game-ending event nodes will spawn outside the visible game board and you were supposed to know scrolling was possible. Also, the game is permadeath, so you have to start all the way from the beginning, just to get to one of the ending routes. That's 20-40 hours spent EACH game, not to complete all the content of the game.;;If that weren't bad enough, new games can start with gamebreaking bugs that prevent essential event nodes, like speaking or cult establishment, and action cards, like passion or health. You can't even change your cult's principles, so you've completely wasted hours on a good run because of something you messed up half an hour in. If you come across an opportunity to bypass any of that mess, chances are it is content locked behind DLC. Ridiculous.

It's amazing, and the music is really well-suited.;But yeah, you have to be willing to try, fail, and try again (oh, and check out its wiki, it'll help a lot)

请埃尔里奇与康妮和我速速结婚——！刃教真是太让人有安全感了（;断断续续玩了三个月，目前还差刃dlc和使徒局没打，因为设定太复杂了各种大佬专门的研究也超多，游戏感受反而很难写orz总之按照游玩顺序想到哪儿写到哪儿吧，本体体验玩法和世界观，dlc体验各种独立的故事。;有剧透;本体：;一开始一直死，不是恐惧死的就是没钱死的，干了不少蠢事，比如不敢吸鸦片，觉得建教风险太大一直在公司上了五六小时的班，试图贿赂警察，对影响很好奇于是在不知道有什么作用的情况下保存了很久的六级影响，没事就单纯的睡觉增加获得恐惧的概率等等等等。;后来某次终于勉强摸到规律了，开始当996教主并燃起了泡NPC的欲望，觉得埃尔里奇大狗狗又可爱（用小刀剔牙）又可靠，在靠他杀穿防剿局后顺便失去了对警察的恐惧。飞升环节纠结了很久，觉得和埃尔里奇过凡人的一生也不错，最后还是觉得好不容易走到这里，沉没成本太高了选择飞升。这大概是本教主在数次降临中最真情实感的一次罢（悲）。;接下来把各个职业和性向都尝试了一下，在发现秘史教可以招四个警察后就对刃教和埃尔里奇移情别恋，康妮才是真老婆（）。;总之各大教派都挺有用的，但从拿多点成就的角度来说，可以把蛾和心教留给舞女，把启教留给教士，把冬教留给食尸鬼。;舞女：;我不过同时和两个人约会罢了，怎么能说我渣呢？;这是个不缺钱的职业，不仅仅可以从金主那里拿到不错的酬劳，甚至可以杀了金主拿一大笔钱，完美满足玩家想体验黑寡妇的心理。身为独立故事线各种信息也很多，能对心和蛾相有进一步的认知。;教士：;非常无私，正统胜利属于牺牲自己让千万人得福。;很穷且利他的职业，甚至要做仪式让自己牺牲更多，一想到身为教主受了那么多折磨，就觉得拿教徒献祭什么的也不过是洒洒水（）;食尸鬼：;美食家模拟器，寻觅不同食材并且制作优质的料理，个人最喜欢的dlc。;开局送温柔好脾气的纸片人老婆，如果品尝美食觉得腻了还随时可以和她聊天。比起其他dlc简直是一股清流，虽然流程长，但是都送老婆了时间什么的也不是重要考虑参数吧！整条故事线节奏舒缓，也有温馨的结局，好评up。;;总体来说是毋庸置疑的良心好游戏，各种网文也对密教世界观做了推广，入手肯定是不亏的，就是上手难度高，在一开始玩还是需要足够的耐心的，建议先别搜攻略，有些谜题自己解开才能获得最大乐趣。等通关使徒和流亡者dlc可能会补充更新一下。

I felt this game was mostly managing without a tutorial until I realized that there are dozens and dozens of symbols for "aspects" in the game you're supposed to learn to recognize. When you try to drop a card into a slot that doesn't have the right aspect, it tells you just the names of the aspects, not the symbols. The only way to learn them is to click on a card then mouse over, one by one, the list of aspects to read what they are. It's a pain to connect what the game is asking you for to what you have.
The game is fun in the beginning when you're figuring things out, but it drags on in the midgame. It's also pretty easy to just go through the motions instead of figuring out how to move forward.

This game is a passion project concluded against all odds by a couple all on their own. It's fun, beautiful, haunting and mysterious in an eloquent way that only the brilliant mind behind it (and Sunless Seas) would be able conceive (and ultimately execute). The writing is nothing short of genius, and to those with an interest in lovecraftian horror and occultism, this game is sure to be a trasure trove. As to the gameplay itself, it strikes an unlikely balance between convoluted and intuitive, but once one gets to grips with it, it's easy to let time slip by (I've more than once spent whole nights playing this game, only to realize that I simply forgot to go to bed, and the birds were already singing outside). Kudos to Alexis and Lottie for this masterpiece.

wow, I never expected this to be that much fun :);;it has some unique qualities... it reminds me of roguelikes because of rng, permadeath and the careful resource management... it has that exploratory mechanics quality that I came to love e.g. Anitchamber for... of course, it does feel like a tabletop game and that's cute in itself... the scraps of the stories that it contains also seem quite interesting ... and it also has this "okay, just one more move" trait that I love/hate since it makes you play until the early hours of the morning or just forget about the errands that you were supposed to run ;p .... ;;anyway, definitely recommended <3;;;

I'm a little shocked I didn't leave a review, so here goes!;;This probably remains my favourite game, and likely will remain that way, for quite a while.  I approached this game as if it were in a vacuum, that is to say I did as much as I could to know as little as possible going into it beyond I was interested.  From there, I made my own notes as I progressed and did the best I could to 'wrestle' the game into submission (as even the game says itself).  There is a lot going on in this game and it can be initially a bit overwhelming.  Organization is key, and finding what works for you helps as you track everything going on.;;The lore and the story of the game I cannot, and would never attempt to, claim to be an SME on the subject.  With that said, what I did experience inspired the imagination.  The process of discovery really made the whole process feel more meaningful.  I feel in a fairly large part that because I didn't push for other endings, or explore deeper, that I've done myself a bit of a disservice and there remains much more to uncover.  That said, I absolutely recommend the game - all I'll say is go in with the understanding that the game mechanics are a kind of language you'll need to learn to make it through.

Lovecraft via solitaire; a difficult and opaque experience, which you should avoid unless you are both curious and patient (and you WILL be).;;If you are willing to sit, think, and read, you will experience one of the most vividly imagined worlds I've yet encountered in a video game.  A world of rarely-rivaled depth and emotion, conveyed in tiny snippets snippets snip snip snip;;UPDATE: Day 47.  The dreams finally make sense.  I have thrown my phone into the sewer; I was only using it as a flashlight to peer into keyholes and locks but I don't need it because they make their own light now.  My wife has left me, and I am free to serve the Mother.  I make sugar and build homes for ants.  I want to tattoo the Stigmata onto my hands and feet and tell the world that Christ's Father in Heaven was his Mother Below, but this would attract the wrong kind of attention.  My hands shake as I write this review, but I will risk prison or extraordinary rendition if it means helping you make an informed choice about whether to buy this game.;;God, I wish I never bought this game.

Look, I want to like this game.;;It's interesting enough. It's got a pretty nice core mechanic of fumbling about with different cards that makes you feel like you're juggling different plates and fiddling with things you definitely cannot comprehend. The opening half-hour of things appearing and disappearing and you still don't really understand how it all works is very much a cool experience.;;And then the grind kicks in. Once you master the basic mechanics and sequences, there really isn't anything that keeps you interested in them. The pause button means there isn't really a sense of tension considering you can frame-perfect all the timing windows whenever you want, and the random number generator of it all gets old really fast. Even otherwise "reliable" ways of generating needed resources to progress are not just frustratingly hidden but also annoyingly random in their results. Does studying this book give you the red card you need or the orange card that does nothing?  Well, could be either! Weird and interesting the first time, but it gets old real quick.;;Not to mention the lack of a tutorial *will* drive you to a guide. If only because of how weird and non-intuitive getting some of the middle- or end-game challenges are. There's a tooltip button that shows you what cards can go where, but that's only helpful to a point. If you want to beat the game, you need a guide. You can do it without one, but it is maddeningly frustrating in the worst way.;;If this is your jam, and you care enough about memorising all the RNG tables and details to put together a real run, and that sounds like a fun time for you, go for your life. I bought this game on a whim, because it was on sale, I think, and it looked like it could be interesting. It certainly was that. I fired up the vanilla game, with zero clue what was going on. I'm 8 hours in now, and have only attained a tiny clue so far. However, the game, presented as a table top game, manages to be both stressful and oddly satisfying to play. It's got a pretty steep learning curve, but with a little persistence, and allowance for several failures, you'll come to appreciate the gameplay, intricate story and low key menace that is the feel to the game. ;;I soldier on, and will eventually conquer this game. My only advice to you, gentle reader, is fall in love with your space bar. Pausing the game is an essential tool. I had no idea at first, but I learned. Quickly.

This is a first for me, in several ways. First time playing a timer-based rogue-like card game with no absolutely no clue about what the game wants for me to survive and win. I found the contents of the game interesting and stimulating, while at the same time excessively frustrating. Try and die. Try and die. Try and die. I began to get the rhythm in one play through only to be killed by RNG. And the advice the game gives after each run seemed to be of very little actual help in successive plays due, I think, to the randomness of both starter options and actual play through events. I then began to see the game for the grind it was and deeply resented the timers and lack of guidance. The game does show glimmers of genius in the ways it simulates real life elements and causes you similarly to share the feelings of your character about anxiety and mundane routine and life needs. For that, it deserves kudos.;;When I was 20, I probably would've loved this game. Now that I'm past 50, not so much. When you have less time left in the world, seems like for me anyway, you tend to have less patience for needlessly mysterious timesucks. And this is also a first for me--first time wishing I could give a neutral review for a game. You might love it. I might revisit it (haven't yet uninstalled). Today, I can't recommend it because of the needlessly steep learning curve combined with the need to sink so much time into learning what could have been made simple with a few insights from the enigma-loving dev(s). The next time I want to torture myself with the elements of life I've already experienced (and endured) combined with the mysterious doings of dark cosmic forces, I'll borrow some books from the library that I don't have time to read and overspend my budget for the month. If there's time left after that, maybe I'll play this game for extra self-loathing misery.

I just wish the game would pull the plug. as you don't know if you are playing it correctly.;;There isn't many instructions on how to play or tactics, for a new player. I felt every single time I was mashing buttons hoping something would highlight, even once I slowed down and read every prompt, I still didn't really have a goal as a player.;It just seems to be one of those games I played it for 5 hours getting better slightly each time, surviving longer. But with little progression. I felt like I only progressed 10%% of what the game actually is. It just became such a grind I just couldn't take it anymore. I guess I just really sucked at this game. ;;It reminds me of minecraft, where you have to rely on external wiki's to understand what is going on but even so after watching a few videos it just felt like a grind. and really took the fun out of what you first experience with this game. After 5 hours I really felt I wasn't achieving anything. Its too much random attributes without a clear goal. If you really like learning obscure rules, this is the game for you. However if this is something you can throw some time into it and eventually finish. its to confusing, you spend more time trying to understand how to balance everything then aiming for the objective. too much going on at once, will overwhelm any causal player. ;;Game also crashed about 4-5 times in the four-ish hours for no reason. Unity just froze up and bottomed out, even more annoying when you are on a good run. ;;I got to the point, that my conclusion was this was lazy game design. As reading the store front, they promote how the game doesn't need a tutorial. So stupid, you just alienated an entire user base. after the 5 hours I really felt like I wasted my time. A tutorial should exist, does not have to reveal everything, but just enough to get you started. Or to lend a helping hand when you are visibly stuck ;;I don't recommend, unless you spend some time watching other people teach you the game online.  Otherwise its a grind and soon as you realise there is no way of telling you, you are doing something right. you have no clue if you are progressing correctly.

If you read game texts, enjoy flavor text and go lore diving you might like this. The lore and presentation intrigued me.;;If you're looking for gameplay - this is a treadmill, that consists of 2 gameplay elements: Crafting and Survival.;;It will take a minute until you notice the crafting aspect (due to the game being cryptic), but there are pretty clear outcomes to every action you take. There's a little bit of randomness here and there, but at the core, you could probably a simplistic script to win this game.;;Survival aspect is just you losing resources passively (some over time, some randomly) and sometimes running into resource checks. You lose if you run empty, on core resources or accumulate too many "bad" cards. Survival element very rarely adds something to a game. In this case it fits thematically, but it's still just game time padding. Look past that padding and you'll see how shallow the core (crafting) side is.

Neat idea and fairly unique in terms of execution, but has a lot of problems. The game is a mashup of a lot of elements but it boils down to a semi-worker placement card game revolving around a lot of trial-and-error and hoping to get lucky with the correct combination of things appearing. This idea works in "Stacklands" because it is quicker, more focused, and not as punishing.;;However, here it is very painful as the "try different combinations to get things to work" takes time, effort, energy, and more all while other things are ticking on in the background. It is very easy to spiral out of control with not having money or enough resources to solve problems that pop up. Not a deal breaker itself, but there are 2 key issues that result in it being a mess.;;First, there are no save slots -- it is a rogue-like where you will be spending hours building up and "rolling the dice" on finding things that can all end abruptly if you mess up or get unlucky. With multiple save slots you could actually experiment and figure stuff out without dooming a multiple hour game from a single tiny mistake.;;And second -- the game often boils down to rolling for specific items over and over hoping to get the correct type of magic to progress. There are 9-ish paths of magic and getting pieces of them is largely random. You meander around collecting fragments of lore to complete a mission and only 1/9th of them are applicable (yes some build / help get others but how would you know without more trial-and-error?). That means you're juggling dozens of things just to hope you roll the dice on finding the right combination you're looking for.;;Even using a Wiki to look up the stuff is difficult because there is just so much thrown together in convoluted ways. This game might have been a borderline recommend if they simple had save states and the ability to undo things... but make some mistakes and you're back to 3+ hours of grinding to get back to where you were all because you did the wrong thing without knowing any better. Ugh.;;Cool idea, neat theme, and fun mechanisms... but the whole execution is a slog. 4/10. Just pick up "Stacklands" instead.

Cultist Simulator is a game filled with unrealized potential. ;;A typical playthrough takes 20+ hours, but only ~5 hours of your first game will be exploring and figuring out how stuff works. Once you've done that, the game degenerates just route 'going through the motions' as you farm up enough resources to achieve your goals.;;One example is exploration. If you want to explore 1 location in the Evening Isles, you need to farm up 16 Chronicles, and each Chronicle has a 33%% chance of dropping from an activity that takes 1 minute to complete... so on average, you'll be doing that exact same activity 48 times per exploration, and you might need to do that exploration 5 times to collect an item you need to win the game, so now you're doing that activity 240 times. That's 3 hours of nothing but grinding chronicles. Absurd. ;;Secondly, the game supposedly has a pretty big focus on lore and mystique, and it does... but only on the surface. You soon learn that the game's lore has very little to do with the actual mechanics, and it doesn't matter if you know who The Colonel is or what The Door in the Eye and the Forge of Days are, or why you would want to invoke any of them. The only thing that matters is that this obstacle needs 10 'lantern' to defeat it, and 'lantern' is basically just 'yellow mana' in the vein of MTG. You never need to (and, in fact, cannot) ever use any of the lore you uncover for solving puzzles or making deductions. It's all irrelevant narrative fluff.;;Finally, Cultist Simulator doesn't actually simulate running a cult. Every cultist you can recruit is identical except for their 'mana' type. They have no personality, desires, or weaknesses. Recruiting them is as simple as saying "join my cult, we have a shiny object" and them going "sounds legit, okay!" at which point they immediately become your willing slave, following any order you give them up to and including killing themselves. It would be a lot more compelling if you actually had to persuade, seduce, or brainwash them into compliance instead of just showing them a cool object you found.

Do [b]NOT[/b] buy this game, I cannot stress this enough. The only thing you'll be 'simulating' is the wait before you become bored and want to play something else. There's only a nondescript board, cards, and timers that activate by using those cards. And these timers can go on upwards of minutes to HOURS. The game sterilizes any intrigue or curiosity you could have about what's going on by making you wait obscene amounts of time just to get another timer and wait some more. ;;If that sounds like fun to you, I won't stop you from wasting your money, but I'd easily recommend other games instead like [b]Loop Hero, Ring of Pain, Hand of Fate 2,[/b] or [b]Inscryption[/b]. Please, look at any of those games over this one. They're definitely more fun and engaging than this shit.

长文警告。;本游戏的巨大信息量和lore深度已经被讨论的很多了，AK甚至还在通过ARG持续更新lore深度（有兴趣的玩家请搜索「虫鸟解密」或直接从[url=https://weatherfactory.biz/enigma]解密[/url]入口进入）。因此这篇评论试图聊点别的——游戏形式。;;1. 本游戏首先是一个「桌游」。;虽说密教模拟器主打带有「资源管理」的「互动叙事」，但游戏自身完全没有隐瞒「卡牌桌游」这点：玩家直接是在一张桌子上进行游戏，游戏中的一切互动要素都以卡牌的形式出现。;游戏的核心gameplay就是在桌面上摆弄卡牌；随机事件由抽卡定夺；每张牌都有对应的面值和所属suit（游戏中称为「性状」）；需要打出相应的牌才能获得更高级的牌（如下副本就是这样一个过程）；收集到足够面值的特定suit卡牌才能通关（比如三个欲望飞升结局都要求凑足面值共计36的对应性相）。;对于熟悉桌游的玩家来说，密教模拟器完全就是一个有较强组合收集（Set Collection）要素的桌面卡牌构筑（Tableau Building）游戏。;游戏跟现实桌游最大的不同也不过是把「出牌-得牌」的过程用「动词方块」（也就是可以放入复数卡牌、外有倒计时的那些正方界面；AK将其称为"verb"或"verb token"）取代。;此外，本游戏还有一个特点是规则繁琐但严谨，到了仿佛需要规则书的地步（但没有任何规则书），比如卡牌必须严格按顺序放置在动词方块里才能被激活——因为搞错了教团卡和清客卡的放置顺序，我花了半小时才搞清楚如何创教。这种严谨规则又是可玩性的一部分，玩家不必重复学习，熟悉机制以后就变成second nature，但熟悉机制的过程非常艰难。某种意义上这点也很桌游。;;2. 本「桌游」意外的「官僚」。;现实中桌游玩家群体一直不大，原因之一即是桌游需要的bookkeeping太多（当然根本原因是价格和不易携带，但这是另一个问题了），而电子游戏赢在可以把大多数bookkeeping交给程序。;密教模拟器几乎是反其道而行之，在一个电子游戏里全面还原了在一张大桌子上管理一万张卡片的感受。;总的gameplay上来说，游戏越深入，探索越远，要管理的卡牌（人和事）越多。游戏甚至把卡牌数量推进到了一个现实桌游都不会有的极端——现实中哪怕打完一局[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/128780/pax-porfiriana]Pax Porfiriana[/url]桌上也不会有那么多牌，因为设计师会尽量避免繁琐的bookkeeping。;电子游戏界有一类「官僚类」游戏，希望通过非常thematic的资源管理来体现某种官僚工作（通常是集权官僚）的繁琐，代表有Papers Please和Beholder。密教模拟器虽然theme完全不同——当邪教头领和当官多少还是有区别的——但其对「互动叙事」的「桌游化」依然抵达了「官僚化」。没有什么比在一张大桌子上管理一万张卡片更官僚的活动；一张卡片可以说就是一份文件。玩家担任一名「管理者」，自然也会需要管理各种繁杂的事务。;密教模拟器在这一点上意外地跟一个著名桌游设计师，[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgamedesigner/6/martin-wallace]Martin Wallace[/url]，的作品同步了。;Wallace设计过所谓的「牌组构筑兵棋」（Deck Building Wargames）三部曲，以[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/79828/few-acres-snow]A Few Acres of Snow[/url]为代表：三代游戏内的一切要素，从军队、地点到运输方式，都是卡牌。玩家需要打出一切对应的卡牌才能进行某项行动——比如如果要从A地发兵抵达B地，玩家需要握有A地的地点卡、AB之间的交通方式卡、以及军队卡，才能进军——相当于一个官员只有拿到一切相关的行政文档才能下令。而玩家每控制一个新的地点，都要抽取该地点的对应牌，游戏越深入手牌越多越难以管理。;可以看出密教模拟器几乎是Wallace这三部曲的Tableau Building版；其流亡者DLC更是跟Wallace另一部作品[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/141517/study-emerald]A Study in Emerald[/url]高度相似（有趣的是，A Study in Emerald也是一个克苏鲁主题桌游——其改编自尼尔盖曼的《绿字研究》）。用密教模拟器制作一个Wallace游戏的mod也不成问题，机制几乎完全通用。;无论是效仿还是英雄所见略同，AK和Wallace都是抓住了「卡牌管理」的「官僚」一面，并将其转为与叙事相符（玩家担任一位「管理者」）的gameplay。;;3. 本游戏证明了一种「桌游电子化」或者「桌游机制表现形式」的可行性。;逛创意工坊的玩家可能会注意到本游戏最受欢迎的mod之一是一个明日方舟mod。该mod至今仍是demo版（作者因为游戏不再支持相机自动移动一类问题而停止了更新）却拥有极高的关注度——一定程度上是因为密教模拟器的桌游机制表现明日方舟的故事或游戏体验都很「合适」。[strike]邪教头领每天派出教徒下地牢摸金掏宝，罗德岛博士每个月派出干员当打手维持治安[/strike];「游戏机制」某种意义上来说也是游戏主题的「表现形式」，我们评估一个游戏的gameplay时，也会或多或少关注其机制能否适用于游戏本身想表达的东西。;AK在很早以前（2016年？）的一篇开发者日志中说过，密教模拟器将是他对互动叙事游戏机制的一次实验。（AK本人正是开发互动叙事RPG出身。）他的实验很成功：密教模拟器证明了「一张桌子上一万张卡片」也能讲述一个庞大的世界观，同时也没有特别落下gameplay。;而「一张桌子上一万张卡片讲述庞大世界观」是源自桌游机制的。AK本人也从不讳言这游戏有多像是电子卡牌构筑混合电子TRPG；他最近甚至出版了一套同世界观下的TRPG规则书。从Martin Wallace的诸多桌游中，我们也可以看到这个机制/系统的巨大可能性——不仅能适用于互动叙事、资源管理，也能驱动政治、军队和大战略的模拟。;最近发售的[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1948280/Stacklands/]Stacklands[/url]即是一个把类似「一切要素都是卡牌」和「桌面卡牌管理」或机制应用到电子游戏的案例，而且是大成功案例。不过相比密教模拟器和Wallace三部曲，Stacklands更接近其老祖宗Dominion（比如这游戏抽卡是...买卡包，gameplay也更简单直接），并且在短时间内产生了大量的仿制品和山寨版。;希望以后能看到更多开发者像AK或者Stacklands开发组一样，意识到桌游和电子游戏之间的互动可能性。

A really cautious recommend. The game introduces experimenting with different cards and different places, and pulls you quite well into the character you're playing. Where it gets a little frustrating is in the interface - place a tile or card in the 'wrong' place on the table and you may have to figure out why the screen's locked up and you can't interact with anything, cards will bounce around the table and you find yourself having to pause just to track down the one you need which may be hiding underneath and so on. It feels cluttery without a way to guide cards to go to certain set places after use or on discovery.;;I'm probably going to be playing more, it's really intrigued me - the writing style I enjoy as I do the fragmented nature of the story telling, but I can certainly already see some of the criticisms about grind within it to creating cards to the timers and having to slot them in the right place at the right moment.

[h1]不再冰冷的洛式世界[/h1]    ;    传统神话的一大特征便是以人塑神，希腊子夺父权，北欧兄弟相争，日本兄妹相恋，华夏上尊下卑。神话由人书写，自然也被人赋予了种种含义。;    克苏鲁“神话”却不具备这一特征，洛老跳脱出自身人类的局限，为我们描绘了一个更加残酷、冰冷、绝望的宇宙。这里的神祇可以看做是宇宙法则的代表，很难以人类狭隘的情感去定义。;    [b]如果把传统神话与克苏鲁神话相结合，会得到怎样有趣的故事？[/b];    密教模拟器由此开创了独属于自己的神话风格，司辰有些代表宇宙法则，还有些则是凡人飞升成神。相较于克苏鲁神话中难以理解的诸位古神，司辰的行为已有逻辑可寻（这方面与传统神话相统一）。;    无形之术的学徒通过典籍记载的只言片语构建司辰们的故事，残片断章中描绘着漫宿残暴、狂野的历史。禁断的文字背后隐藏着对未知的恐惧，司辰的动机也许可以解释，然而祂们的力量与行为方式，已经远非人类可以理解之物了。;    漫宿因此而栩栩如生，权力、爱情、妒忌、争斗，此地不再冰冷；漫宿也因此而恐怖诡秘，献祭爱人、阉割以敬神、剥皮以成神、洞开己身而飞升，此处容不得仁慈。;;[h1]加上些许人间烟火[/h1];    加班当社畜、熬夜研读典籍，同时还要夜行漫宿，不能忘了公众场合语及怪力乱神，当然还得时刻关注探险队进展[spoiler]（ 看看是不是又该掏钱了）[/spoiler]，也别把警探晾一边[spoiler] （ 否则啥时候给你送进去的都不知道）[/spoiler]。就这多线程操作，称教主一个时间管理大师绝对不过分（[spoiler] 也难怪浓情蜜意的时节教主没伴侣反而觉得安逸[strike] 吾辈楷模 [/strike][/spoiler]）。;    此番种种，描绘了一个挣扎求生于1920年代的雄心勃勃的教主。青年、警探、医生、富家子弟，机缘巧合下获悉了禁忌的诱惑，决心脱离凡庸的束缚。这故事常见于俗套的修仙小说，然而得益于本作优秀的叙事功底与氛围渲染，飞升之路同样对屏幕前的玩家充满诱惑。;    与此同时，本作设置了大量的世俗结局——警探晋升高位、职员担任经理、舞者接受求婚、流亡者销声匿迹。不论结局难易，每一个都精心编写了文案，言语间毫不吝啬赞美之词，对玩家在世俗中取得的成就给出了肯定（一般的克系游戏是不屑于俗世功业的）。;    [strike] 恋爱模拟器 [/strike]，“我听过一个故事：天平一端为一颗心脏，另一端为一片羽毛。”羽毛昭示飞升，心脏则代表爱情，在大功业成功的前夕，你是否愿意放弃飞升，与爱人共度余生？如果你的答案是“我愿意”，那么恭喜你，你将收获20多段不同的恋爱经历，或炽烈，或忠贞，或奇妙，或平淡。但始终不变的，是教主与信徒共同研习无形之术后，那洗尽铅华的美好。;;[h1]辅以出色的玩法[/h1];    本作几乎将玩法做到了极致，健康、理智、激情的三维升级，步步攀升的职工之路，巧妙地将夜行漫宿与寻宝机制结合，密传与影响的合并与拗转，仪式的方式与所需物品的结合。许多的机制与技巧隐藏的极为巧妙，随着游玩时间的增加，你不禁会惊呼：“原来还能这样！”;    奖励机制以外，还有诸多限制如影随形。猎人紧追不舍地搜集证据，恐惧、入迷的强烈压迫，每声钟响连带的生存压力，伴随着异质的渴求撩拨着心弦。精心设计的阻碍与背景相结合，飞升之路的每一步都遍布艰辛。;;[h1]点睛之笔是本土化翻译[/h1];    部分神祇的名讳：The meniscate，The door in the eye, The madrugad;    祂们统称为：Hours;    神祇的居屋：Mansus;    如何信达雅地翻译以上词汇？;    且看翻译组是如何做到的：;    部分神祇的名讳：弧月，瞳中之扉, 昕旦;    祂们统称为：司辰;    神祇的居屋：漫宿;    “夜不能寐，侧耳倾听。微风穿梭于枝桠间，窃窃私语。房屋沉溺于自己的梦中，大声呼号。这皆是混沌所经之路。”;    “当我们注视火焰时，我们所视何物？我们找到此物时，它会说出：一个赋予转变神性的词汇，此改变随烧焦的皮肤剥落而出现。”;    这只是一些例子，你很难想象这样带着疯狂的诗意会出现在一个翻译作品中，同样很难想象这些语句不用中文表达的意境。然而翻译团队做到了，做到了以文字构建如梦似幻的奇异世界。;;[h1]难道就没什么缺陷吗[/h1];    当然有，本作目前有很多小bug，这些小bug也许并不影响主要的游戏体验，但每当它发生，总归还是不太舒服的。例如，有些卡会被莫名其妙的一直被吸入正在进行的进程之中，一直持续到该进程结束为止，持续不断的噪音着实令人懊恼。;    本体玩法较为重复，本作的新鲜感主要是由文字来构建的，这也就导致如果玩家漏看了某些文案，或者干脆手快直接收取了，烦躁感与疲惫会骤然增加。再加上大部分本体职业的开局除了小部分剧情不一样，其余的流程都是相似的，时间一长，难免不想再重复这一枯燥的过程。（当然这一现象在DLC中得到了很好的改善）;;[h1]结语[/h1];    文字的魅力总是无穷的，相较于其他媒介，私以为文字是最为激发想象力的载体。这也是本作得以成功的主要原因——独特的神话体系构建出的秘氛与文字的配合天衣无缝，每句话、每个字的背后都有着引人遐想的迷思。放任想象遨游于纷乱迷幻却又真实可感的异世，探寻潜藏在世界表皮下的色彩，亦如飞蛾扑火，那光满溢而出，狂乱而又充满诱惑。;;;;;;;;[h1]后记[/h1];    感谢你能看到最后，以下是废话时间。;    本作极其适合未接触过克苏鲁文化的玩家作为入门之作，这也是以我本人的经验得出的。之前向几位老友推荐克系文学，收效甚微。毕竟克系文化以绝望为底色，洛老原作大量的形容词让人望而却步。真正出名的几部，如《墙中之鼠》、《印斯茅斯的阴霾》、《疯狂山脉》、《敦威治恐怖事件》，都有较强的叙事主线逻辑，其余的诸如《星之彩》、《暗夜呢喃》，则很难说有什么故事性，文字与描写都艰深晦涩。;    这部本来是打算抱着试试看的心态推荐了一下，当时一并推荐的还有《灵魂摆渡人》这样休闲的种田游戏，对比这样轻松愉快的作品，《密教模拟器》很难说的上是亲民，自然没报太大期望。然而结果却令人惊讶，好兄弟拿着我的账号一连一个多星期，每天从下午到晚上都在研习无形之术，最终与我协力把时间刷到了123.7个小时。这热情着实令我欣喜，在我的刻板印象中，克系文化一直是小众爱好，也因此我开始反思本作的与众不同，思考它与原教旨克苏鲁神话的区别，评测的创作契机便由此而来。;    我本人一向是比较反感原教旨主义克苏鲁神话的。的确，洛老对于恐怖文学的贡献绝对是开拓性的，但这并不代表后人对于克苏鲁神话体系的补充和完善就是错误的。也许克苏鲁神话也因此被加入了很多被视为幼稚的元素——旧日支配者有了阵营与元素、相生相克，但也正是这些工作，才使得这样一个亚文化得以走向大众的视野，剔除恐惧，放大神秘，克苏鲁文化得以成功影响21世纪的大量恢弘的叙事作品。（最近比较火的网文《诡秘之主》也正是如此，虽然我不爱看网文，但这部的名声还是有所耳闻）

Some people may consider a game like this to be tedious or pointless, but I really enjoy this one for a number of reasons. See there's two ways you can play Cultist Simulator really, you can choose weakness and go to a wiki or something and look up all the information for what does what, you can go to guides to learn strategies to win the game. Alternatively, and I highly suggest this route myself, you can play it how I think its meant to be played, forget all about wikis and guides, pretend this is the mid 90s and you'd be lucky if anyone on a forum even talked about your favourite game. Buy a corkboard and a bunch of red string and thumbtacks, start taking notes as you go. Realise you may have screwed up royally and keep notes of your 'poor life choices' and find out that it wasn't poor life choices, just a different stepping stone on the path to an over-all eldritch greatness...or death, death is always an option. If you'd rather chicken out of all that though I suppose you could settle into a desk job for the rest of your mortal life too. ;;I suppose if you make it through to the other side, I might see you there. Good luck! Oh also, you can eat your boss, that's fun too.

Cultist Simulator transports me to a world where magic is real. ;;First, the mood is set with a stirring, curious, ominous, and, occasionally frantic soundtrack. The gameplay allows you to go at exactly your preferred pace. It's shocking how urgent a game can feel when I spend so much of it paused. This pacing draws me in, invites me to flow.;;It is suggested that you explore and take risks, which will certainly be necessary as the game does not hold your hand or tell you what to do. Nonetheless, if you are resourceful, you will rarely get stuck.;;Every piece is important, but I must give some special attention to the writing. It's so beautiful, poignant, and evocative. It sparks my imagination and makes me long to return to a world that never was. The writing is a rainy, lamp-lit night in the city. It's a suspicious glance from a stranger waiting outside a door. It's grasping at the dimly recalled scraps of your dream, and feeling that some deep significance is slipping through your fingers. If only you could remember.;;This game makes me want to believe in the occult. I've searched for some of the people/media referenced in the game, hoping some of it is real. Perhaps some things are better left imagined.

Basically, once you have a plan and understand what your goals are the limitations become much more apparent and time-consuming, and in my opinion not worth it. ;;The game is about experimentation, and once that's gone so is the game. A very cool concept, though, and one that I hope to see explored more. Also, the fact that you can't box-select in this game when a vast majority of it is laying out the shitloads of cards you end up with seems... less than ideal. I want to stress that I really enjoyed the mechanics, but they only work well in the context of someone learning to play the game.;;All in all, worth the money, but not a game I would play more than once or twice. If you're looking at this game and you enjoy choice-based games or choose your own adventure books, then you're on the right track. Otherwise I would proceed with caution.

It's a great game, though I have some reservations about it.;;THE CASE FOR:;;- Novel approach to gameplay.  Very engaging.;- Unique, captivating setting -- especially The Exile.  The world of Cultist Simulator is sinister, complex, and uncanny, and a ton of fun to read about and piece together.;- Aesthetic, writing, and soundtrack all complement each other very skillfully.;- High degree of challenge ensures that victories are hard-earned and rewarding.  Figuring out the right approach to a problem is a lot of fun.;;THE CASE AGAINST:;;- The core gameplay is based on timers counting down.  Not bad in and of itself, except that it can hook the player's mind to an inconvenient degree, the same way that idle incrementers do.  It's a game that's hard to pull yourself away from, sure, but for the wrong reasons.;- The game's opening screen and manual both encourage experimentation, but I find that to be difficult given the amount of things that are going on simultaneously.  When the game has around 6+ countdown timers for different tasks of varying complexity running simultaneously, it's exceedingly difficult to focus on one particular endeavor long enough to learn organically how to do it successfully.  Simultaneously learning how to manage the character's mental health, public suspicion, expeditions, cult, secret knowledge, Mansus excursions, and so on is practically impossible without a guide.;- Upon which note, it winds up being one of those games that benefits to an almost comical degree from having the wiki open.  There are way too many moving parts for this game for wiki abuse to not be a thing.  We're talking about a game in which victory requires you to collect and use several dozen different "book" items, all with impossible-to-remember names, about a fifth of which unleash potentially deadly mental conditions on your character when you use them.  We're talking about a game in which victory requires you to send expeditions to dozens of vaults, each of which requires a different combination of follower skills to complete successfully, and sending the wrong followers gets them all permanently injured or killed.  We're talking about a game in which most of your midgame and endgame progression depends on the Mansus, each visit to which has you open one of three doors to receive one item from each door's loot table of three to six items -- oh, and there are fifteen different doors and you'll never remember which door to try to open to get what you want at any given time, unless you have a wiki tab open.  It's a problem.;;All in all, though, I like the game, and I'm interested to see what's next for this franchise.  I did beat New Game+; without getting too far into my strategy, I'll say that my MVP was a nameless "Experienced Swindler" hireling that I picked up within the first few minutes and made heavy use of until the very moment of my victory.  I didn't even end up sacrificing him to the Spider Door when I was in a jam near the end; I didn't have the heart to after how much he helped me over the course of the game.  Thanks and good luck in your future swindling endeavors, buddy.

Why delve into the invisible arts, an endeavour as profitable as a roaring opium habit, as ethical as burning libraries, and in general as beneficial as intentionally stepping on a venomous serpent?  Well, perhaps you read for a degree so useless even the morgue wouldn't hire you.  Or you had every comfort you could imagine, and then the dreams began.  Or you, ahem, borrowed seventy-seven years of some poor sod's life and didn't think the rest through.  Regardless, welcome to the Mansus, glory is up, worms are down, and either you suck up to the Platonic ideals with attitude that own the place or you find your own way to go toe-to-toe with them.  Don't like those options?  Tough, you'll like being a raving lunatic or serving a life sentence for crimes you're not allowed to know exist less.  You can always be deader, after all.;;So those are the choices: better enjoy the long climb up.  And once you've gotten your bearings, there's a real pleasure to laying all your cards out, sitting back while your long-suffering minions bust open yet another ancient tomb or summon a living firestorm to incinerate the reluctant plod who just wanted to go back to reading his paper in peace, and using forbidden rituals to transform your body into something very much not quite human.  And oh, you will learn, you will learn to see patterns in the mad kaleidoscope of books and letters and tantras.  Perhaps you'll even come to understand, if dimly, some pretty deuced important things, like why daybreak is wan and the sunset bleeds in the evenings; whether Vienna still exists; and how the end of everything will begin.  (Not with a deicide, but with a pilgrimage.);;But not the true mysteries.  Where, exactly, your spurned lover buried her eye.  Who Janus is, or was, or will be.  And why your beloved cat is aligned with the devouring lusts of the Red Grail.  I followed mine around and pestered it for an answer-- in vain.  But perhaps you will find out.  Rise higher, see further.  The dreams are imaginary, but the delight is real.  Into the fire you fly.

Honestly I got this game because it was recommended to me a few times by steam, but now I really wish steam's refund period wasn't mere 2 hours of game time. The initial curiousity of the first two hours makes way to confusion, which in it's own term gets replaced with annoyance and irritation afterwards. ;;To put it simply, the game didn't made me feel like a cultist. You're playing as a deranged man who struggles to navigate his life between crippling depression and insanity, all while trying to stop your funds from dwindling so that you didn't suffer a death from hunger or deteriorating health. You wouldn't even be thinking about occult things for the first several hours because you'll be busy stabilizing your existence. And once you do reach the occult you'll find that it's just a glorified Mahjong. ;;The gameplay isn't automated in any way and is incredibly repetitive. Basically the real gameplay is figuring stuff out, once you do the game just becomes a stable loop.

Imagine this scenario.  You're cleaning out your grandparents garage when a dust old box falls on your head.  You peek inside and you find something that looks like a board game or ouiji board or magic / chemistry set, you're not sure because instead of English or Greek or Chinese, the game and rules appear to be written in a sparse script that looks unlike anything you've ever seen.  You spend a few hours trying to make sense of it and put it away.  ;;But somethings is lingering in the back of your mind about that game.  Was it... alchemical?  occult?  You come back to the box, and spend a few more hours.  The game comes with a deck of cards and tiles, and it seems to be responding to your moves, even though you don't know what you're doing.  Suddenly a week later, you realize you've played with your occult sorcery set every single night this week.  What's more, you somehow understand it, even though you don't want to bother trying to put the complex system of magic and logic into words.;;That's basically the type of transformative experience of trying to win this game without looking up the rules.  Every time you play you'll figure out something new.  The game will TRAIN you to play it, if you allow it to.;;The complexity of the game is disguised by the inherently intuitive mechanics.  The  actual lore and narrative... well I feel like I'm just starting to get past the first phase of rules and the narrative there is great, but I don't honestly know how deep or complex it gets yet.  But the part that keeps me coming back is that feeling I described, of deciphering an occult artifact that unlocks new connections on the board and in your mind in concert.

And really top-notch Chinese localization work btw.;;+ elegant mechanism design;+ delicious feast if you like learning by doing;+ prefer imagination more than graphics;+ feel like home if you're a tabletop player;;- skip it if you hate reading;- skip it if you hate playing card;- skip it if you like playing with guide;- buggy, glitchy UI on linux, maybe not on Windows;

Literally one of my favorite games. I own this game on the PC, my phone and a tablet, with the tablet being my favorite interface.  I've probably dumped 300-400 hrs total in to this game, and have (across all accounts) gotten most of the endings.  ;;Weather Factory has managed to take a simple, time-based resource game and turn it in to a dark, resource organizing puzzle.  The sound is brilliant, giving a tactile feel to most actions, ambient music that is relaxing and driving at the same time, and that frames the decisions that you make quite nicely.  The dream-break noise, in particular, is a fantastic flourish.;;The UI, while not perfect, is perfectly functional.  I rarely run in to major problems, with the sole frustration I have being that occasionally the game will unorganize your cards on rebooting, and lump them in the center of the table, resulting in a frustrating few minutes moving things about.  I have noticed several complaints about the new UI, but perhaps it has been patched, because I haven't had any issues as of yet.. It's definitely not unplayable as some are claiming.;;I would say the real drive here, and the reason I likely enjoy it so much, is the lack of information provided to the player, and the blind fumbling that necessarily ensues on your first few playthroughs.  The game seems to provide you with juuust enough information to keep you interested in finding out more, and rewards (and punishes) experimentation.  With enough time, most of these systems start to make sense, and you can plan elaborately and far ahead of what is going on in the game.;;The last thing I love about this game is its fun permutation on rogue-likes.  Some choices and results of some runs carry through to the next... and getting some of the best ends requires sacrifice and repetition.  Major endings can take a long, long time to complete, and it can feel great to knock one of them off the list of to-dos.  ;;Final words on this fantastic game : It's a beautiful, time-oriented resource manager with stellar audio choices, difficult to parse choices, and it requires experimental learning to master.  Do yourself a favor, and buy this game.  And when you do, try to avoid looking information up.  The beauty of this game is the blind choices, and the learning from run to run how the game works.  Read carefully, check aspects & know that it might take a while to figure some stuff out.

I think Cultist Simulator is an incredible puzzle/storytelling experience. Alexis Kennedy (the writer) has quite the reputation in video game storytelling and it shows in cultist simulator.;;The game can be quite obtuse sometimes, but the answer is in the game I promise. You just have to know where to look.;;This is a game about YOU, not some character in the game. YOU have to figure out how the game works, YOU have to figure out what the clues in the lore you find means. YOU have to decide how the game ends.;;That might be a turn off for you, and that's ok. This game is also quite clearly a refined proof of concept (it also doesn't help that it's Weather Factory's first game). There are some janky mechanics and a reliance on RNG in some places of the game, although coming from an XCOM enthusiast perspective, this doesn't bother me. Though it might bother you.;;It is a well written, if mechanically rough, game about Apocalypse and Yearning.;;Overall I'd give it an 9.3/10. Definitely try it out if you like deep story and puzzles.

I love this game. I wish it loved me back. ;;So much of my time spent in this game is spent wishing there were actually decent usability features. The point, at least on the first playthrough, is to figure out how the cards interact with each other to tell a compelling narrative, but about halfway through that playthrough, you start playing "Organize Your Cards" simulator. It's atrocious; group moving is inconsistent at best, the raw quantity of cards makes organization near impossible, the separation and constant fading of certain kinds of status effects like reputation and mental ailments makes organization a never-ending battle, and most importantly, under certain extremely common conditions like "there are too many timers on the board," the game slows to an absolutely unplayable crawl, where even fast-forwarded time ends up slower than real-life time. If this game had a sort function, or even passable optimization, or like... any sort of opinion on how you should be organizing your board, I'd enjoy it a lot more than I do. ;;God, please let me just hit sort. Please let things with different timers stack. Please stop making me hit "pause" every 2 seconds so I can figure out where my cards got scattered to. ;;Or don't, I've already lost like 2 days, so...;;Update: Played through to one of the major endings. Towards the end of the game, I spent about 5 hours doing about as many expeditions because the raw number of cards on the screen made the framerate and timer tick-rate slow to an abysmal 5 frames per second, causing in-game time to be even slower than real-world time, even on fast-forward. The game became borderline unplayable, and it speaks to the quality of the worldbuilding and writing that I wanted to keep going despite the absolute hell that was the actual experience of playing it. Honestly, even if that were not the case, the game became the least interesting grind of "hope RNGesus finally lets you win.";;At this point, my recommended way to experience this game is to play through to a standard ending once to get the experience of discovery, then read a wiki somewhere to actually get to read the excellent writing.

I have 250 hours in this game.  I have gotten every major victory other than the Exile DLC.  I very much like this game.;;However, as it is right now I cannot recommend it.;;Currently, the UI is a mess because of changes that were forced out before they were ready.  It has been like this for a long time and the developers have not learned form their mistakes.  I understand that game development is hard.  I sure as hell couldn't do it.  But what I do know, and what I do practice in my own work, is knowing when you've created a bigger problem than the one yo are trying to solve.  The UI before worked 99%% of the time.  It was within completely admirable tolerances.  Maybe there were underlying issues that the developers wanted to iron out, but if there is a problem the user never perceives then is it really a problem?;;Even then, it is possible to play this under the classic branch and have the same UI as before.  But I still have to call foul, because the developer response to backlash has been awful.  If someone complains that your game is needlessly broken, it is not OK to ban them.  It is not a breach of rules to be angry about a product you purchased being torn apart in some ind of insane vanity project.  The attitude of the head developer has been terrible, and has severely tarnished my views of Weather Factory and their products as a result.;;None of this had to happen.  But they decided it should happen, and that it should continue to happen, and as long as it continues like this I have to give one of my favorite games a negative rating.

Many games have great lore, few games do a good job at making the lore matter in any meaningful way when it comes to playing the game itself. The Elder Scrolls might have a fascinating history, with multiple clashing perspectives that may or may not be all facets of a single truth, but none of that actually matters to the vast majority of people fucking around in Skyrim. Not really. And knowing it is certainly not a prerequisite to, you know, playing the game.;;Some people will claim that Cultist Simulator doesn't provide any direction. They are incorrect. It's just not in the places you expect, and has a generous dose of in-universe obfuscation lathered on top.;;Cultist Simulator, more so than any other game I've played yet, requires study of the in-game lore to get the most out of. Not just reading, but genuine, honest to god study. You have to be willing to re-read things that you think you already know, not just because the game involves a decent amount of grind if you're lost, but because the meaning of a sentence can change dramatically depending on what you, the player, know about this world. There are passages of text in this game that provide shockingly straightforward advice for attaining your ascension (carry the marks of your desire to ascend to the Stag Door) the problem is that the in-universe authors assume you already know what they're talking about. You don't and sometimes you stumble onto solutions. Other times, you need to figure it out the hard way.;;Oh, and just like real-life occultists, sometimes they just lie to you and expect you to figure out what's a lie and what's the truth. Or sometimes they're just wrong. It's up to you to figure that out.;;The key to enjoying this game is to accept that you're going to have to stop and think long and hard about lots of Proper Nouns and obscure symbolism and whether or not you're missing a piece of the puzzle or are just failing to recognise a clue. This is not a game for everyone, and that's okay. No game is.;;However, if you're interested like me in the bizarre and frustrating world of occult research, where half the shit is made up and the other half is written by someone who actively wanted to stop the "uninitiated" from understanding what was going on, but this time with rituals that actually work... there's nothing else like Cultist Simulator.

fantastic worldbuilding, perfectly fitting music and this game is in many parts brilliantly written and a beautiful homage to lovecraftian horror, i like the world so much that i have bought the physical copy of the lady afterwards to support the developers, yet,  before you buy keep the following points in mind:;this game feels a lot more like a tabletop game than a videogame in many aspects, it has issues with its pacing and it certainly sacrifices gameplay for flavor in certain parts, also the game is brutally hard if played without a guide, in fact i'd say this game often will make you lose a 10+ hour run over a little mistake, it doesn't hold your hand and barely has a tutorial, which is nice in one way but the issue is that this is not only a management game, but also a puzzle game that requires you to solve very obtuse and obscure puzzles to progress to the next stage of the game and it does this not once, not twice but at least in 4 different instances, it also can screw you over with rng REALLY heavily if you are unlucky, which would again be fine if the runs didn't last 9+ hours each, 4+ if you know what you are doing.;the dlcs add a lot of extra worldbuilding and make some of the less useful aspects (basically alchemical elements of the mind) actually usable but they add a whole slew of new systems that often feel even more unfair, or they flip everything you know about the game and require another 15 hours of bonking your head against a wall to comprehend what is happening/4 hours of wiki consultation and memorizing new routes (yes i am talking about you the exile, oh you beautiful yet frustrating mess of a dlc).;also recently the devs are trying to push a new ui that is just... ugh, awful, the grid snapping is absolutely horrid for a card game that has a very strong tabletop feel and i often find my immersion broken by the horrid controls and ui.;the game also has the classic issue of "lets add an achievement for every minor variation of an ending" which again becomes an ugly problem for completionists when each run lasts an eternity and you could mess everything up with a small mistake along the way,;last but not least we come to the main pet peeve i have with the game: the repetition;the initial 1-2 hours of each run will be spent in similar ways, grinding your skills to an acceptable level to be sure that you won't die because you were low on funds one cycle or you stall your progress later on to a halt because you didn't have the skills to merge the correct lore safely, also the way you obtain lore is gonna be the same at the start of all runs: go to oriflamme or morland's shop to empty their stock, hope you get STUMM! from oriflamme early so that you can start doing rituals without wasting too many resources, profit.;still after this wall of critique i can't recommend to try this game enough, its a unique experience that offers a mistery and world like few others in gaming, maybe don't try to be a completionist with it though.

这是一个神明和超自然力量真实存在的世界，而我将在其中扮演一位高贵的教主。我将统御庞大的教团，我将施展魔法，摧毁一切阻拦；我将压榨教众，享尽荣华富贵……;不，以上都不存在。实际上我不得不每天打工挣钱避免饿死，但凡旷工一天就有降职之虞。研究方面勤勤恳恳学外语、翻译文献、写论文，但写出来还当不了第一作者，只能交给伯爵、教授他们换取佣金。感情方面还要洁身自好，如果同时和多个教众开展恋爱关系还会招致怨恨……或许当教主和读博也相差无几吧。;[spoiler] “当教主讲究的是一个名正言顺，七成归防剿局，三成归赞助人。” “那我呢？” “你接着给格洛弗父子996打工就行了。” [/spoiler];;剧情方面：此游戏内容极多，文本量极大，设定极繁复，且翻译相当优秀（颇有密教神神叨叨的感觉），喜欢宏大世界观的玩家不要错过。;游戏性方面：提示略少，如果不熟练的话不妨对照wiki进行游玩，否则会有较强烈的挫败感。且内容丰富度有限（虽然有排列组合生成的大量不同文本，但游戏性上重复度较高，玩个几周目都背下来了）中后期和多次游玩之后会有单调感。;手感方面：有待优化，截止于2022.6.x版本，拖拽手感不佳且有bug，在属性-测试版中切换回旧版本会好一点但依然不够舒适。

I don't even know what to say about this game. It's gotten its hooks into me for 200+ hours, and I feel like I'm not done with it. In essence, you play an individual in a vaguely Victorian setting who learns there are hidden mysteries that underpin our world. By finding the right artifacts and lore, and attracting the right followers, you can unlock the secrets of these mysteries and gain the attention of godlike beings called the Hours. Play your cards right (see what I did there?), and you can pass through the otherworldly Mansus and receive your final reward.;;To accomplish this, you play cards (wait, I should have put this first for the pun to make sense. DAMMIT.). I don't want to say too much about the mechanics, because the core gameplay loop is figuring *out* the mechanics. You have to experiment with card placements, "Verbs" (action slots such as Study, Dream, or Work), ingredients, and other elements to see what effects you can conjure.;;It seems simple at first, but it's deep and compelling gameplay. I love this game and you should buy it.;;Pros:;• the game is the rules, making for a unique experience;• intriguing setting that hints at a larger world/mythos;• shades of cosmic horror in a totally different direction than Cthulhu;• lots of endings make for significant replayability;;Cons:;• will consume your life;• punishing save mechanism (or lack thereof) means you fail a lot;• can feel a bit grindy in the mid-game;

When I first picked up this game I was beginning a phase of the Lovecraftian horror kind and seeing that the game matched my interests, thought I'd give it a try. I could not have stumbled into a better masterpiece of literature, aesthetic, and game design than this. That being said if you're not interested in horrors beyond the comprehension of mere mortals, (aka if you don't already like lovecraftian story elements) this might not be the game for you. If you do however feel ready to bask in the all the glory and horror you can bite off and chew, I could not recommend this game enough. The thing that makes it amazing is how the writing builds on the world of the game in a way that makes you want to understand more. The mechanics are simple in theory, but the farther you go and the better you get the more it feels like you're actually there, herding the powers of gods, gracefully standing on the edge of the knife. This game is a masterpiece for the lore lovers, the deep divers, and the atmosphere drinkers.  Don't let any other reviews convince you otherwise, this game is amazing and deserves your attention. ;;Let the games begin, and may the odds be ever in your favor.

After the glitter and the mystery wears off and you as a player finally find a goal to achieve, all that's left is a grind-fest. One that takes hours upon hours of clicking the same actions to progress in a chosen direction, and can be shattered with just a few unlucky, dread-ful results. I really want to like this game, and I love all things filled with curiosity and imagination, but this one just has too much repeated clicking and disappointment.

This game is strange, well-written, and atmospheric. It's amazing at creating the feeling that you're picking up scraps of information about something you understand extremely poorly, and then actually having those pieces of lore come together into a cohesive whole at the end. Figuring out how to game the system by any means possible during the Apostate runs is also a great deal of fun, surviving in one of those is terrifying and definitely makes the game feel fresh. I am attempting to get all the achievements for the sole reason that I am incredibly foolish, and I'm only 40%% of the way through.

A deeply infuriating downgrade to the "Choose your Adventure" genre that not only does not take bookmarks, but requires one flip through pages 1-20 every 60 seconds, and every branching choice has a 50%% chance to simply not do anything, even if it might be important on the other side of a coinflip, while sighing and pointing back to page 1.

Be prepared to go down the rabbit hole when you pick up this game. It's grindy at times, but very fun.;;You must plan your steps by yourself, with the crumbs of information that the game presents to you by some very pleasurable writing.;;You have to grow a lot as a character to even get close to a victory ending (except the minor ones, perhaps), and you learn a lot of the game's mechanics in the process.;;The "seasons" keep you on your toes as you must react to the sequences of events that are thrown at you: Sometimes you're being investigated and suffering from despair or fascination at the same time. Not being prepared or being overcommitted to something else (an expedition, perhaps) could spell doom for your run.

Perhaps one of the best choice I've made on Steam.;;The game is fun and aesthetically pleasing. I enjoyed reading the lore, discovering my way forwards and being constantly challenged as I go further in the game. The learning curve is a bit steep and defeats later in the game tend to be very frustrating (after all, watching all you've built up crumble in 60 seconds is very unpleasant). ;There is a lot of thing to explore in the game, with a wide varieties of legacy to start from, so there is always something interesting to dive into. I recommend playing it blind, but there's no shame in looking up what to do next and what's the victory conditions are. Additionally, I also recommend setting aside some time to sit down and play the game, as a victory isn't something you can finish in just 1-2 hrs. Once you've made it past the harsh learning hurdle at the beginning, you'll begin to see and appreciate what the game has to offer.

8/10;Pros:;        1.相当充足的文本量，故事也十分吸引人[strike]需要一定的脑洞才不会觉得无聊[/strike];        2.可重玩性很高，能产生周目之间联动;        3.虽说只是类似桌游的2d卡牌游戏却有相当高的自由度;Cons:;        1.bug略多，经常出现一张卡拖出操作框时反复回到原框内的问题（小退解决）;        2.指引很少，其实算是优点，自己慢慢摸索很快乐（来自一个15h第一次力量胜利的灯教主）;[b]不在Steam打开不会计入游玩时间和成就！！！[/b];[h1]以下是对萌新玩家的一点点帮助(仅保证你能活下来)[/h1][spoiler];;[h2]消除负面情绪[/h2];[b]前期没做主线不要乱碰入梦[/b]，金钱入梦拿安逸/金钱探索褪衣俱乐部，放入恐惧+安逸能够把恐惧消掉；放入入迷+恐惧/一瞬追忆也可以消，前者更优。躁动可以通过想象技能工作（画画）消掉，甚至能出安逸。恐惧、入迷等是很重要的资源牌，在满三围前基本不可替代。可以画画保鲜,你看不到的牌不会被吸走。（有说法说揪住的牌也不会被吸走不知道是不是真的lmao）;[h2]消除邪名和证据[/h2];可以画画保鲜邪名，[strike]用此技巧保护邪名并制造密氛来当垫子.[/strike][b]一定要去看自动吸钱的“时间流逝”右边标出来的下回合事件！尤其是留恐惧入迷升级的时候！[/b];邪名产出证据后可以跟蛾属性教徒对话消掉，或者直接搬迁基地基本全消。[b]蛾属性小弟也可以逼疯上司或者警官（刃可以刀掉）[/b]，但可以不搞第一个警察，后面出来的都带词缀。[b]小弟不到5性相就别上去送辣![/b];[h2]其他[/h2];基地推荐书店（很多次购买之后会空出来）或者教堂（小萌新见解）。;开头可以不先打开遗赠，而是锻炼三围，顺带产出技能。;仪式之间没有作用区别（除了通关用的置闰仪式），是依据你放的教义和性相决定作用的。仪式之间区别只是素材不同。;最后附上准则之间的拗转表;灯→铸→刃→冬→心→杯→蛾→灯，除秘史外都可变成启（其实都挺好理解）[/spoiler]

I very nearly refunded this the first time I played it. The mechanics are intended to encourage experimentation, but really they just make the game opaque and frustrating. The second time I played, I used the wiki and this quickly became one of my favourite games.;;Use the wiki. It helps.

This game doesn't allow you to play it the way it wants you to play it.;;The game is heavily focused on experimentation, it puts you in the driver's seat and lets you figure out what things do what. However, there is absolutely no form of action tracking or action history.;;With tons of cards and permutations, it becomes exhausting to keep track of all the combinations that actually resulted in an intended action/consequence.;;Clicking on a Verb slot lets you see which cards might be placed in there, but only for a second, resulting in spam clicks to see what is possible. Even then, slotting in those cards might add additional slots that are required to be filled in, which you may not have.;;The game gives you no guidance on what types of cards go together. It gives you no guidance about what the icons mean on the UI.;;Good idea, bad execution.
